sp.p: No; not at all. I ſtraggled all I could againſt it. He could not do what he intended, by reaſon of my then ſituation. He did not meddle with me any more, only pulled my hand to him; I told him I thought it was impoffible that any creature could take pleaſure in ſuch vile abominations: there was nothing more particular that night, that I know of. On Saturday morning he got up, and ſent Mrs. Griffinburg in to take me up When ſhe came in I was very i • : ſhe deſired I would not ſtay to dreſs myſelf there, but ſaid I muſt go into another room, and had me into another room which I had not ſeen before, where there was a bed. When I was got there, ſhe ſeeing the condition I was in, aſked me if I would go to bed again: I told her no; but finding I could not ſtand it, I told her yes, I would. I went to bed, and laid about two hours; but they came ſo often to me, that I could not get any ſleep. They came and took me up: they ſent the maid in to drets me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Who is ſhe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I do not know her name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Had you any converiation with the maid?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
No. Then there came a woman to take meaſure of me for a gown. Juſt after that Mrs. Griffinburg came in, and ſaid my Lord wanted me in his room. I went in. He aſked me what I would have for a gown? I ſaid I don't care any thing about it; I would as lief wear what I have. He ſaid, would I have blue? I told
him it might be blue if it would, I did not care. He ſaw ſome bruiſes upon my hand, as he ſtood at the window, upon my hand and arm both, and aſked how they came; I told him he did it the firſt night, and that he had made it worſe again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Was that true?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: It was ſtrictly true. I went into that room where I was at firſt, and they brought me up ſome gauzes and petticoats, and ſaid I muſt chuſe ſome; but he had fixed upon the colour of the petticoat himſelf; and as for the gauzes, I told her I did not care, ſhe might take which ſhe pleaſed. I took the petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did any thing elſe paſs?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: She ſaid, as I was a milliner, I could make the caps myſelf. My Lord ſaid the petticoat ſhould be a light one, and that was light.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did you hear my Lord ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I think I did, but am not ſure. I ſaid I was ſo ill I could not work there. She deſired I would tell her what I wanted more; I ſat down ſomething about wires, but I don't know what. The • aid left the pen and ink, but came back again in a 〈◊〉 . I aſked her if ſhe could not leave it, becauſe I wanted it: ſhe ſaid no, ſhe could not, ſhe would bring it again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What did you want it for?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: To write to my father, and fling it out of the window.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did ſhe bring you the pens and ink?

sp.speaker: S Woodcock
sp.p: No. Mrs. Griffinburg deſired I would take the work and work with the ladies. I took an apron and ruffles to make; and there was a lady to drink tea that day; after tea, Lord Baltimore ſaid, he thought the ladies ſhould go te cards. The eldelt Miſs entreated me very much to play, but I refuſed, and ſaid I could not: I did not chuſe it. As ſoon as they had got to play, I retired to the next room; Mrs. Griffinburg came unto me, and told me ſhe wanted me to ſee the apartment ſhe had been preparing for me, for that I could not have that room I was in in the morning; thereſore ſhe carried me up into a ſtone garret: it ſeemed to be all ſtone; it was very cold, and ſtruck like a well, and was among all the fervants, that I was very much frightened and uneafy about it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Was there a window?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
There was a window cut out of the leading; I could ſee nothing but a bit of the leading of the
houſe, which looked out upon the gutter, and a bit of a ſky light. I was very much frightened and uneaſy, and thought it very odd I could not have a better room in ſuch a houſe as that. I was afraid that now he had done with me himſelf, that he did intend I ſhould be expoſed to any body that he might ſend. Upon that I told Mrs. Griffinburg that I durſt not lie there; ſhe, upon that, ſaid, to oblige me, ſhe would bring up a little bed, and He there a night or two. Then I came down ſtairs again to ſupper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: With whom did you ſup?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: With the lady that came to ſee him, Doctor Griffinburg, Madam Saunier, and the governeſs, the two Miſſes, and Lord Baltimore; but I neither eat nor drank. On Sunday I kept up in the garret, and they came often and diſturbed me, that I could have no reſt any where. I came down ſtairs to breakfaſt, and then went up again, and came down again to dinner; and after dinner I ſtood up at the window, and as I was sſtanding up at the window, (this was the corner window, and looked toward Hampſtead) as I was ſtanding, I thought I ſaw Mr. Davis. the perſon to whom I was engaged.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Who was in the room with you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
Two more ladies that came to dinner that day, Madam Saunier, and the governeſs and the two children, and myſelf; they ſix were ſtanding up at the fire ſide while I went to the window; there I ſaw Mr. Davis; and when I firſt ſaw him I was ſo ſtruck I could not tell how to ſtand; and fearing that he ſhould not ſee me, when he looked up I thought he did not know me; but he went behind a wall towards the Foundling Hoſpital, and there peeped two or three times, till I was ſure he knew me. He took a book out of his pocket, and made a motion with his hand for me to write; with that I waved my hand for him to come further, but he did not underſtand me; therefore, when I went to the next window, at firſt ſight I loſt him, but ſeeing him again, I waved my hand for him to come further, and then I ran into the next room, which was the room Lord Baltimore generally ſat in; but I ran in hap hazard, without thinking whether he was there or no, and called out to him in great agony, I cannot come to you! I cannot come to you! This was the other corner room, the weſt ſide of the houſe; I croſſed the room the bow-window is in, to go to that
room. He ſaid are you well? But I prevented him, by aſking, is my father well! He ſaid Yes, he is well, and we are all well; he ſaid then, how do you do? Then he ſaid, where is Mrs. Harvey? I ſaid I knew nothing of her. He then ſaid, is all well? With that I was ready to drop: I ſaid, good bye, and ſhut down the window.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What was the reaſon of that?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
I feared ſome of the women would come; and before I could get out of the room Lord Baltimore came in. I was ſo flurried and was all in a tremble, that I did not ſpeak to him as he came in, nor he to me. After this I intreated the maid to get me a pen, ink, and paper, and bring it up into my room, meaning the garret, and not tell any body of it, becauſe I wanted it to amuſe me. I lay in the garret that night, and next morning ſhe brought me a pen and ink. I began to write immediately to my father, but was ſo prevented that I could not go on with my letter: this is a part of it (produced) I did not throw it out of the window: This was on Monday morning. While I was writing this letter, Mrs. Griffinburg came, and ſaid the milliner had brought me ſome caps; I ſaid I did not care to come down: I told Mrs. Griffinburg ſhe might take what ſhe pleaſed; ſhe ſaid, I muſt go down: With that, I went to the milliner; ſhe had brought ſome caps and cloaks: With that, I took one that I thought looked the decenteſt, and that was all; Mrs. Griffinburgh intreated me very much to ſpeak for more things: and ſaid I muſt have ſome aprons. I aſked the woman if ſhe had any flowered muſlin; ſhe ſaid, ſhe would bring it when ſhe came again; that was the ſubſtance of what paſſed then. I went and I had my breakfaſt with the family; Then I went up into my garret again, and Mrs. Griffinburg came after me. I aſked where my Lord was? ſhe aſked if I wanted him? I told her, yes. I wanted to know if ever he intended I ſhould ſee my friends again; for I could not bear to live ſo. She deſired I would take my work and go down ſtairs; which accordingly I did: And ſoon after I came in, Lord Baltimore came in, and clapt me upon the ſhoulder, as I ſat with my back to the door; and told me he was coming to tell me ſomething that would pleaſe me very much, that I ſhould ſee my father that day without fail: With this, to be ſure I was pleaſed, and went up ſtairs with intent to put my things on. Mrs. Griffinburgh followed me, and ſaid my father, was ſent for to come to her houſe, and that I muſt make
haſte, and go directly; for he would be there before I could get there; ſhe helped to put on my things; and I came down ſtairs into the room next the Foundling Hoſpital; there was a lady that had been there the day before. Lord Baltimore began to tell her what a religious lady I was; and that he was ſorry for many things he had ſaid to me. What his reaſon was for this I don't know, except he thought I ſhould expoſe him too much. Some time after this, he led me into another room; and when he got me there, he ſaid I now was going to ſee my father; that he was ſent for, and I was going to Mrs. Griffinburg's to meet him. He told me I muſt ſay I was willing to ſtay; and if I would tell my father I was ſatisfied and eaſy, he would do any thing for me that I deſired: I 〈◊〉 him that I would, but I muſt ſee my father alone: He ſaid, then he would ſpeak to him firſt. I told him, he might, but I would ſpeak to him alone.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Explain your meaning.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
My meaning was this, Sir, that I might put him into ſome way of geting me away, if I could not get away with him; then he ſaid, I ſhould take the little Miſs, and I ſhould ſay to my father, I was a companion of that lady; to that I only ſaid, very well: Then we were ſent on to Mrs. Griffinburg's houſe, with an intent to meet my father, in Dean ſtreet, Soho; I went to this houſe; when I was there, I ſaid to Mrs. Griffinburg, I thought you ſaid my father would be here, before I ſhould get here; but I ſee you have deceived me, as you have done all along. She ſaid he would come preſently. In about two hours after this, or rather more, Lord Baltimore and Dr. Griffinburg came. As ſoon as he came in, I ſaid, I thought you told me I was to ſee my father; but I ſee you have deceived me, as you have all along; and I ſee I ſhall not ſee my ſather to-night; he ſaid, yes, you ſhall: But what do you think has happened? Your father has taken up Mrs. Harvey, and put her into the round-houſe: This gave me ſome pleaſure, but I dared not ſhew it; I did not know what to anſwer; at laſt, I ſaid, I did not ſuppoſe that would do any good, for ſhe would not tell where I was: Soon after this, in came another man, and ſaid, Lord Baltimore's houſe was beſet with Juſtice Fielding's men: He fell into a paſſion, and ſaid my father muſt be a fine man indeed, to ſet to work ſuch rogues as Juſtice Fielding, and his men, were, that they were the greateſt
rognes that could be. I was frightened, and thought my life and my friends were in danger, becauſe he was in ſuch a rage; and I was afraid, having much about the ſame opinion of him, that he had of Juſtice Fielding, that may-be he might ſend ſome of his men and ſet the homſe on fire, or do ſome miſchief. After this there was a great demur about Mrs. Harvey's being at the round-houſe, and how they ſhould get at her, and get her bailed: Sometime after this, I found that Mrs. Griffinburg had been to ſet if ſhe could come at her; Mrs. Griffinburg ſaid ſo, that ſhe could not; with that they were in a great taking, in what 〈◊〉 to proceed to get this woman bailed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Who was?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Lord Baltimore, and Dr. and Mrs. Griffinburg; then I ſtudied what I ſhould ſay and do: At laſt, I ſaid, that if they had got Mrs. Harvey (I ſpoke to Lord Baltimore) they might depend upon it, they would never deliever her up, till I was ſet at liberty: I told them, if they had a mind Mrs. Harvey ſhould be ſet free, it muſt be me that could do it; and if they would let me ſee my father, and I could ſettle things to my mind, I could releaſe her if I pleaſed. In two or three hours they got a man to go, upon account of ſpeaking Engliſh: they ſaid, if Dr. Griffinburg went, they ſuppoſed that the old man (meaning my father) would think he ſhould be run away with: Then they got ſome tradeſman to go along with them to carry the letter, which I had then wrote, if I remember right, at Dr. Griffinburg's, to my father.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What was the purport of that letter?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: The intent of it was for my father to come to me: We went then to Whitechapel; I went in a coach with Lord Baltimore, Dr. Griffinburg, this man, the Doctor's niece, and the little girl: This was on Monday.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Was there any ſervants attending the coach?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
I ſaw one run on the ſide of the coach as I went; it was Pierini, they call him the valet de chambre: We ment to a tavern; I cannot ſay what it was; I believe I ſhould know it again, if I ſaw it: There was only a little boy that led the way up to a back room: When we came there, this man, the tradefinan, was ſent with the letter to my father: He came back and brought word, that my father had been out ever ſince nine in the morning, in ſearch of me, and brought the
letter back. I was very loth to go back again; I did not know what to do. I wrote to the landlord of our houſe, to tell my father to be as eaſy as he could; for I would ſend for him next morning at ten, as Lord Baltimore told me I ſhould: At that time at the tavern he told me I ſhould ſend for him in the morning: It was the land-lord of my father's houſe, whoſe name is Berry. The tradelman brought word back again, my father was not come home as yet; ſo Lord Baltimore would go back again, and ſaid, he ſuppoſed they were making a fine piece of work at the other end of the town. We went back; and when we came to Covent-Garden, the coach ſtopped, and the tradeſman got out, and went to Juſtice Fielding's, according to their orders.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did he come back again?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He did, along with Juſtice Fielding's clerk, who brought a card, with his compliments, and that I ſhould ſee my friends there: I did not know what to ſay to the man; I made no anſwer, but gave the card into Lord Baltimore's hand; he read it, and ſaid I ſhould not go. With that, I told the man to tell my friends, that I was there (I mean at Dr. Griffinburg's houſe) and that I deſired my friends to come to me there directly; the man did not come any more; but there was meſſenger after meſſenger, came to tell him of men being about the houſe, and a great mob in the yard; and withal, that there was ſome women had been crying there. With that, I was afraid it ſhould come out, that I had ſeen Mr. Davis at the window. I begged of my Lord, to let me ſpeak to the man firſt. I found there was another meſſenger come about ſomething; I went out of the room, and there was Broughton, which we call the Steward: I aſked him what the woman ſaid? He ſaid I was ſeen out of the window; I told him I was, and I wanted to ſpeak to him about that. I told him I thought that my life depended on its being known; and therefore begged, if he had any value for a perſon's life, he would not mention to my Lord, that I was ſeen at the window. He ſaid he would promiſe no ſuch think, his bread depended upon 〈◊〉 . I told him he need not fear his bread, he might get it another way. At laſt, he promiſed me, that he would not tell him unleſs he aſked him. Then I came into the room, and what paſſed, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What was the reaſon of this application to conceal it from my Lord?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
I thought may-be he would murder me that night, or ſend me away. After this there was a great deal of conſuſion, and they talked in another language; I was fearful they were contriving to go ſome other way, or ſend me abroad. My Lord was ſo frightened, he was afraid to go home for fear they ſhould take me out of the coach: I told him they could not take me out unleſs I would, and that I would not go with Juſtice Fielding's men. After ſome time, we ſet out to go to Lord Baltimore's again. When we came within two or three doors, the coach ſtopped, by whoſe order I do not know; Right againſt the coach there were ſeveral men ſtanding; I got up to ſee if I could ſee any of my friends; but Lord Baltimore pulled me down, aſked me what I got up for, and ordered the coach to drive on immediately: which they did as faſt as they could; and the men ſtrove to'get into the yard along with the coach; Juſtice Fielding's men, I believe they were; they ſtrove to get into the gates, and getting out of the coach, I cried out, let the men come in: He pulled me in, and ſaid I ſhould not ſtay. With that, we went up ſtairs; when we got there, the little Jew came up, and ſaid, my Lord, Piereni wants you: With that, I got up, and walked about the room in great diſtreſs, fearing it was coming out that I had been ſeen out of the window. I thought I would ſtrive to hide it; I plucked up all the courage I could, and aſked him as ſoon as he came in, what Piereni wanted. He ſaid I had ſpoke to ſomebody out of the window; I told him I had; he aſked what I had ſaid: I told him; but did not tell my diſtreſs becauſe I was afraid: When I had told him, he ſaid he could not blame me, he ſhould have done the ſame himſelf. He ſuppoſed I was glad to ſpeak to the firſt I had ſeen. With this, I was rejoiced, I had been in ſuch a terror before, leſt he thould kill me for it. After this, he and the doctor talked a good while in ſome other language; what, I don't know. By and by, Lord Baltimore ſaid I muſt go to bed to him; that I muſt lie with him that night, or he ſhould be wretched: I 〈◊〉 ; he promiſed me be would not meddle with me; I thought if I did not, he would make me go to bed to him, ſo I did go to bed to him, and he did not meddle with me. On Tueſday morning he got up firſt, and went away, and ſent Mrs. Griffinburg to take me up. She came, and ſaid Lord Baltimore wanted me directly: With that, I got up and went to him. When
I came to him, he ſaid, Well, now we will write to your father, and ſend for him as propoſed. I had heard over night, that one Mr. Watts was to come in the morning at ten o'clock: So I ſaid I thought it was better to ſtay till ten o'clock, before I ſent to my father. I thought it would be Mr. Davis would come by the name of Watts. At ten o'clock I wrote a letter to my father, the purport of which, if I remember right, was this, that I begged my friends would come with all the decency and reſpect becoming a nobleman's houſe: He took the letter, and ſhewed it Mr. Brown, the attorney, and ſeemed very much pleaſed with it, and ſent it away. After this, he wanted to know what I ſhould ſay to my father, and whether I would ſay as I had told him, that I was willing to ſtay. I ſaid I would, but I would ſee my father alone by myſelf. With that, he ſaid, he would do any thing to make me eaſy. With that, I ſaid very well, but could not tell what to anſwer him. He ſaid I ſhould have a houſe to live in, and live with my friends, if I liked it better than living with him. Juſt upon that, Piereni came in, and ſaid, my Lord, here is Mr. Watts come; but before that, I ſhould have told you, my Lord ſaid, that whoever came, I muſt ſay I was willing to ſtay. The man came up, and ſaid, there was Mr. Watts. Lord Baltimore went out to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Who was left with you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't know; there was Mrs. Griffinburg and Dr. Griffinburg, backwards and forwards; but whether they were in the room or no, I can't ſay. My Lord brought Mr. Watts up ſtairs; he was in the firſt room, and I was in the fartheſt room; he was brought up ſtairs; The doors happened to ſtand a jar, that I could juſt ſee them, but I could not hear them. It I remember right, there was Piereni in the middle room. My Lord talked with Mr. Watts for about ten minutes; and then my Lord came firſt, and Mr. Watts almoſt behind him; and my Lord ſaid, Miſs, here is a friend of your's; I ſaid, I don't know the gentleman: He then ſaid, Miſs, you don't know me, nor do I know you; but I am come from your friends, to know if you are here by your own conſent? I anſwered, yes; but I want to ſee my father.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: In that very form of words?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
I think it was; I was in ſuch a flurry at that time, I can't be poſitive. He ſaid, very well, Miſs, if you are here with your own conſent, no body has a right
to take you away; your ſervant, Madam; and then he talked with Lord Baltimore again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What happened to you after this?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I went into the next room; I did not know what to think of Mr. Watts, and I had no thoughts at that time of a lawyer; therefore I went into the middle of the room, to ſee if I could ſee any friends about; when I ſaw none, I opened the window; this was on the firſt floor: I ſaw ſeveral friends at that time, but one pretty near that I knew, Mr. Cay: He aſked me, if I was there by my own conſent? I ſaid yes; but I ſaid I wanted to ſee my father. He ſaid, my father would never come within thoſe walls; I then turned away in a great trembling, and ſaid, then I never ſhall ſee him; that was my way of thinking at that time; I thought, that as they would not let him come in, I ſhould never get out. After that, Lord Paltimore came in again, and ſaid, I muſt go to Lord Mansfield's, and ſaid, I muſt ſay I was there with my own conſent, and not to tell Lord Mansfield particulars.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Let me aſk you this queſtion: Did you before this time, know Lord Mansfield?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I never, as I know of, heard his name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Don't you take in the news-papers?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, Sir, I did not think of his being a magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did Lord Baltimore explain to you, who he was, or why you was to go to him?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Lord Baltimore ſaid, if I did not ſtand by him now, he ſhould be undone: He then ſaid, will you be faithful to me now, and keep your word; otherwiſe I am undone? I ſaid I would? but I would tell my Lord Mansfield, that I wanted to ſee my father alone. He ſaid, if I would be eaſy, and tell him I was eaſy and ſatisfied, I ſhould have a houſe, and live with my friends, and have the young man. With that, I told him I would ſay, I was willing to be there, as I promiſed him before, but would ſee my friends alone. He aſked, if I would tell my friends the particulars? I told him, yes; I would tell my friends all the truth. After this, he ſaid very little. Another meſſage came for him. He came up, and ſaid, we were to go to Lord Mansfield's immediately. I ſaid, very well, I was very willing. Mr. Brown, the lawyer, my Lord, and myſelf, went together in Mr. Brown's chariot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did you know the buſineſs you was going there upon?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Now tell all that paſſed?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: As ſoon as I came into Lord Mansfield's doors, my Lord Baltimore had hold of my hand up the ſteps; I clapt my hand upon Mr. Potts, one of the gentlemen that ſtood in the hall, whom I knew; and he took no notice of me; which ſtruct me very much; becauſe Lord Baltimore had told me, that my friends would not look upon me; and ſeeing ſuch a repulſe from Mr. Potts it ſtruck me very much; I ſaw ſeveral other of my friends there; but I did not ſpeak to any body, nor any body to me; I went into another room, and Lord Mansfield met me at the door? Lord Mansfield aſked me to come in; and Lord Baltimore was to ſtay in the next room; then Lord Mansfield and I were alone, only another gentlemen preſent. I was not then appriſed who Lord Mansfield was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Tell, diſtinctly, what paſſed between you and Lord Mansfield.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: The firſt words that I remember, were theſe: Child, was you carried there againſt your will?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I ſaid, yes, my Lord. He then aſked me, if I was kept there againſt my will; I ſaid, quite againſt my will; my Lord then ſaid, quite againſt your will; I ſaid again, quite againſt my will. He was going to aſk me ſomething; but what the words were, I don't know; I ſaid, my Lord, I don't care to go into particulars.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Why did you not tell my Lord Mansfield at that time?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: It was becauſe I did not know, that he had power to releaſe me; if I had known, I ſhould certainly have told him what had happened. He then ſaid, Miſs, I think you are of age? I ſaid, yes: He ſaid, well, Child, are you willing to ſtay with this man? I ſaid, my Lord, as things are as they are, I am willing, but not without ſeeing my friends alone: He aſked me, what friends? I ſaid my father and my ſiſters. He deſired them to be called. Then he ordered the man would bring Lord Baltimore through ſuch a place, and take me out at the other door, that I might not ſee my Lord, and there I met my friends alone.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did Lord Mansfield ſtay in the room?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Who were thoſe friends?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: My father and the next ſiſter to me. Soon after that, my other ſiſter came; there was no other perſon that I remember, when I was with my friends, I aſked them, if Lord Mansfield had a power to ſet me at liberty? They aſſured me, he had; I aſked it again? They ſaid, yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did the queſtions come from you to them, or they put the queſtions to you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't take upon me to ſay how that was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What did you ſay?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I ſaid, I was heartily willing to go home with them, and deſired Lord Mansfield might be called directly, that I might tell him I would go home. Lord Mansfield came to the door.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Who was in the room?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: My father, and two ſiſters; he ſaid, child are you willing to go home with Lord Balimore, or your father? I ſaid with my father, my Lord, if it is in your power to let me go; he ſaid, child it is in my power to let you go; but how comes this change of mind? I ſaid, my Lord, becauſe till I ſaw them, I did not know you had power to releaſe me; he then ſaid child, it is in my power to let you go, let your friends be called, that they may hear your declaration.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Do you know whether Lord Mansfield explained to you at firſt his power to releaſe you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He might do it, but I do not remember he did. My friends were called in, and will give you an account of what was ſaid: I was ſo overjoyed when I found myſelf ſet at full liberty, that I did not then tell my father or ſiſter what had happened.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: I believe you went away?

sp.speaker: S Woodcock
sp.p: Yes, that I did very joyfully.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Before you went away, did you acquaint your father and ſiſter what had happened to you.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Then you went to Sir John Fieldings?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: At whoſe deſire?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: My friends carried me there, I do not know the reaſon of my going there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What paſſed between you and Sir John?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Sir John aſked me what had paſſed, I told him in a ſew words.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: You was in a room by yourſelf with him?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not quite, there were ſome with me, one or two, but I do not know who.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Was he the firſt perſon to whom you related it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: After Sir John heard the ſtory, what paſſed then?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Sir John aſked me, if I was not full of indignation at ſuch uſage, and aſked me if I was willing to proſecute Lord Baltimore. I anſwered, yes, if it could be done with ſafety.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What did you mean by this?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I meant, that as he was a man of ſo much money and power, that there might be a great deal of bribery, and that juſtice might not be done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: I believe there was an information taken from your own mouth?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did it contain the whole of the ſtory?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, only anſwers to ſuch queſtions as Juſtice Fielding aſked me. From thence I went to a friend's houſe; I have not been at my father's ſince for fear, and am afraid to go in the ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: It ſeems to me, as if you might have had ſome chance of eſcaping from the tavern in Whitechapel?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I had no chance of making my eſcape, for Lord Baltimore, Dr. Griffinburg, his neice, and the little girl were in the room all the time, and Lord Baltimore led me by the arm in and out; there was a man I met in the entry, I had a great mind to ſpeak to, but ſeeing Lord Baltimore had got four or five of his ſervants with him, I dared not ſay any thing to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Had he got ſo many?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I ſaw four or five, there was Piereni, and I think I ſaw two or three in livery.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You ſay, you have not been at home, ſince the affair happened?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I have been with ſeveral of my friends.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: With what friends?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p:
The firſt I went to was Mr. Cay, I ſtaid with him one night: from there I went to Mr. Ridgeway's, I ſtaid there from Tueſday night to Friday; from there I went to Mr. Wilſon's, ſtaid there from Friday to
Sunday; on Sunday I went to Mr. Wallis's, and ſtaid there till the Monday ſen'night.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You have been very much hurried and fatigued in ſhifting about?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: From there I went to Mr. Yeoman's at Weſtminſter, I ſtaid there from that Monday to the Monday three weeks? and from thence I went to Mr. Rutt's in Friday ſtreet, and ſtayed there from Monday to the Friday • e'nnight; from Mr. Rutt's, I went to Mr. Keene's, and ſtaid from that time till the fourth week after my going, and from thence I went to Mr. Wallis's; I went to no other perſons till I came to Kingſton.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What, not to Mr. Potts's?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Are all or either of theſe gentlemen concerned in carrying on this proſecution, you are not able to do it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: A ſet of gentlemen have lent my father money, upon a note of hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I underſtand from your evidence, that you was brought to my houſe without knowing where you was coming to; that you was, during the whole time you was there, under abſolute confinement; that you would have get away if any opportunity had offered and if any opportunity of complaining had offered, you would have done it; do you inſiſt upon this as the truth?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I think I underſtand you, that for the firſt four days, you neither eat nor drank any thing?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, the firſt two days, to my knowledge, I don't know that I eat any thing, from Wedneſday till Saturday morning.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: And then you only had a diſh of tea?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, Sir,

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I did not underſtand from your evidence, that you had eat any thing till Sunday dinner?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: The toaſt and wine I had on Saturday night.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you take any thing ſolid?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't remember that I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You muſt be very much exhauſted, and yet on Sunday you had a long diſcourſe with me, to prove that there was a God, a heaven, a hell, and ſubjects of that kind; how old are you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I am twenty-ſeven.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Will you ſwear you are no older.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I will ſwear I am twenty-eight.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Will you ſwear you are no older?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I will ſwear I am that.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Will you ſwear you are no older?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I do not know I need tell; I am twentynine, and that is my age; I cannot exactly tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: To the beſt of your belief, how old are you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe I am thirty next July, I cannot be ſure of that, whether I am or no.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How often had you ſeen me, before you was brought to my houſe.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Only three times.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You have told us I expreſſed ſome reſpect and attachment to you; had I never taken the opportunity to give you a civil ſalute, when you was behind the counter!

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, you never did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You talked of my having ſaid, I would bring a lady to you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I underſtood you, that you would bring a lady.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Might I not have ſaid, I would ſend?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I underſtood that you would bring.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You have told us, you never ſaw Harvey, but twice before this time?

sp.speaker: S Woodcock
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Iſaacs before?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Iſaacs, I never ſaw before.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You had no ſuſpicion where you was going?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then you truſted yourſelf with this woman, you had never ſeen but twice before. You have given an account of drinking tea, the amuſement at tetotum, the ſeeing the houſe, and ſupper, that there was ſome rudeneſs offered that night, and that you reſented it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was that repeated the next day?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't remember.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did any thing happen the next day, either to make you more alarmed, or make you eaſier. Was any rudeneſs offered the ſecond night?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Nothing indecent as I can remember, but violent threats of doing for me.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p:
I think you ſaid ſomething of Mr.
Smith's drawing your picture; that Mr. Smith was there the third day, drawing your picture?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: That was a man that was called Richard Smith; Lord Baltimore took that name, and then he ſaid he was not Richard Smith, but it was ſomebody elſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it upon the ſecond or the third day?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I think the ſecond day; I reckoned it the ſecond day, becauſe I did not reckon Wedneſday one; it was on Friday.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you take any refreſhment that day?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You ſay, you was even crying at the time your picture was taking; that you neither drank tea, nor ſupped; in what room did the reſt of the company drink tea and ſup?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In the room with the bow-window, that looks into Southampton-row.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: That bow-window commands a view of ſeven or eight foot paths, that branch off; does it not? Do you recollect that Mr. Smith was of the party that drank tea and ſupped that day?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe he was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray will you tell me when you firſt heard that I had ſent any thing to your father?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: On Friday.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who did you hear it from firſt?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Lord Baltimore; when I was pleading, that if he had no compaſſion for me, he might have for my father.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did it come from me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe it did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not Dr. Griffinburgh tell you firſt of all, that I had ſent a ſum of money to your father?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't remember that he did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you expreſs great ſatisfaction upon hearing I had ſent ſuch a ſum of money to your father?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: If I underſtood you, you did not lie down till Friday night; and that you did not pull off your cloaths while in the houſe.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I did on Sunday night; but I never had my cloaths off before.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p:
You have given an account of your
going to Woodcote; had you any notion, when you go into the coach, that you was going to Woodcote?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had no-body told you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You was given to underſtand by me, that you was to to take an airing, and come back, and then ſee your father.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: In your firſt information, as read in the King's-Bench, you ſaid you was carried into the coach by force, and they told you, you was going to Woodcote. You have deſcribed your ſitting in the coach between me and Mrs. Harvey; Did you ſit forward or backward?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: My face was to the horſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You ſaid, Mrs. Harvey was ordered by me to ſit forward, ſo as to ſhut up the window as well as poſſible.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: So that you could not ſo well ſee the people as they paſſed by.—You ſaid that, when the coach ſtopt, you wiſhed it might overturn.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: My reaſon was, I hoped that, by that means I might have made my eſcape, if any opportunity had happened. The coach did not ſtop at all, as I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was the glaſſes down, or up?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: They were up, till we got off the ſtones; and then Lord Baltimore put one of them down a little.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, as ſoon as you found that, inſtead of being carried out for an airing, you was carried further; you was ill diſpoſed to partake of the mirth that went forward in the coach.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I underſtand, you did not know you was going to Woodcote, till you came to Epſom: there are a great many ſteps, are there not, that lead up to the houſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who got out of the coach firſt?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't tell; I was led up the ſteps directly.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Into what room;

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe the firſt room; we ſtaid there ſome time.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did I propoſe to take an airing in the park?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I might go out, but I can't ſay whether I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to know if you will ſwear now, that when you went out of the door to the canal, you did not lay hold of my 〈◊〉 , and run along with me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't know that I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: It is a pretty ſtrong circumſtance; did you go upon the canal before dinner?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, before dinner.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What time did you ſet out from Lord Baltimore's houſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: About two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What time did you get to Woodcote?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: About four.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How ſoon might you dine?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe in about half an hour?

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where did you dine?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In the great dining-room, up one pair of ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: It was there the firſt inſult was offered behind the curtain, was it not?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.
Lord Baltimore, Was it at that time that I talked to you of coming to bed, that I told you it muſt be that night?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, he ſaid it muſt be that night; I got away from him; I don't know that I made him any anſwer to it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you ſay, upon your oath, that when I talked to you of your coming to bed that night, that you ſaid nothing?

sp.speaker: S. Woodock.
sp.p: I told him, I would ſooner give him my life a hundred times over.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Upon your oath, did not you ſay, if I would uſe you faithfully and tenderly, you would let me go to bed to you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I ſaid no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you not ſay, ſome other time might be more convenient.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where did you drink tea?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not the magnificence of that place ſtrike you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, it did; though I would rather have been in the pooreſt cottage.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you ſay, that you believed that room was finer than any room in the Queen's Palace?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't know; poſſibly I might.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I think you told us, you eat nothing at ſupper?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I eat a little bit, but drank nothing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then you did not drink ſeveral glaſſes of wine to my health? Who firſt withdrew to go to bed?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I am not poſitive.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it not me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I believe it was Mrs. Griffinburgh?

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you and Mrs. Harvey go out of the room before me, to go to bed, or after?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Before.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How long might you be in the room before you was put into my room?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I cannot form any judgment.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Can you recollect your deſiring to have a little water to waſh your feet?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No? the women propoſed it: they talked of my having water to waſh my feet, but I refuſed it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How ſoon, after you got into the room, was it, before you obſerved Dr. Griffinburg in the room?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Not many minutes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it almoſt immediately?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe almoſt, but can't exactly ſay.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: The Doctor, I think, did not interpoſe in any other manner than by endeavouring to comfort you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: It is pretty extraordinary, that Dr. Griffinburg ſhould be in the room at all, at ſuch a time; what reaſon did he give?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: You muſt aſk that of him, Sir; I did not hear him give any reaſon.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: The two women led you into my room; can you tell, whether the doctor ſtaid, or went away?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p:
You have given an account of the womens having put you to bed, of having tucked up the cloaths, and going out of the room; and that in the morning I got up to open the door to you; you
have deſcribed the inſults offered you; I ſhall not wound your modeſty, to repeat the account of them. —Did you ſleep that night?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Not at all that I know.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did I?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He lay very ſtill the whole night, I don't know whether he was aſleep.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You have deſcribed yourſelf as being under dreadful apprehenſions, left I ſhould repeat it a ſecond time, why did you not endeavour to ſave yourſelf from that ſecond inſult, by endeavouring to get out of bed, and find your way out of the room?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: For this reaſon; I was in ſuch a fright, I dared not ſtir hand or foot, for fear he ſhould hear me, and turn to me.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: In what room did you breakfaſt, in the morning?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In the firſt room below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: At what time?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't particularly tell that.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You had ſo far compoſed yourſelf, that you had intended to do every thing that was only trivial; to give into my ways, and for that reaſon you pinned the ribbons on; did not you puſſ them up according to the faſhion, that I ſaid they were puffed up too high?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: They are puffed up no higher than are commonly done.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You wore the hat I preſume?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Now as to theſe ribbons, you ſay they were new made up ribbons, but that they were made up by requeſt of Mrs. Harvey, and the other woman?— Did not you think that breaking in upon your rule?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did it by compulſion, not by free choice

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you think any force would be uſed?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: They were very rough with me, and I thought they would be rougher, if I did refuſe it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How long might you wear theſe vibbons?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe all the time.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: At your breaſt?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I believe I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did the two women wear them?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Some of the millenery goods were gauze, were they not?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you make Mrs. Harvey a preſent of ſome gauze?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you recollect, among other amuſements, your being carried to ſee the houſe, and the library. Was there not a book of prints that took your fancy?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I did look at them. The Doctor brought them into the room for me to look at, but not at my deſire.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You was ſometimes in the park, and ſometimes on the water?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Once upon the water that day.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: It was uſeleſs to you to diſcover any particular grief for what had happened, and you did not diſcover it in your countenance?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In my counenance I did, I was very dull.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You eat and drank at dinner?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: The ſame at ſupper?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: There was a gloom then. You was out of ſpirits, and melancholy; where did you lie that night?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: With Mrs. Harvey.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: It was thought a little ſtrange and extraordinary that I did not want again to lie with you. I think you and all the company laughed heartily upon the occaſion: Will you deny that?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I will: I was glad he did not lie with me again, but I did not laugh about it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was there any laughing upon the occaſion?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I think upon the next day you made a viſit with Dr. Griffinburgh, to ſee a poor woman in the houſe who had broke her leg?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, Dr. Griffinburg carried me to ſee her, but not at my deſire.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe while he ſtayed in that room, you went down for your hat and cloak to take a walk in the park?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: We went all in the park together, but this was when we came back.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then you don't recollect your going out of that room for your hat and cloak, to take a turn with Dr. Griffinburgh; how many times might you have been in the park with Mrs Griffinburg only?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Not above once.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you recollect being on the other ſide of the pales above the canal with Mrs. Griffinburg only?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How far might you go with Mrs. Griffinburg only?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: About half a furlong.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe there were a great many workmen laying out a piece of ground by the canal?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: There were.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: And there were workmen altering a ſtair caſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, there were, and putting up paper.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then for the reaſons you have given, you did not think right to mention to any body what had happened to you while you were at Woodcote? what day did the viſitors come from London?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: The viſiters came on Wedneſday, two gentlemen and a lady.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You was ſufficiently compoſed to receive the lady, and do the honours of the houſe, to wait on the lady, and ſhew her the pictures, and what you thought might be agreeable to her?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: She had a mind to ſee the pictures, and I ſhewed her the pictures in the room ſhe was in.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you aſſiſt in preparing the ſheets, and putting the things in order for the exhibition?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe I did take a needle, in order to do a little of it; not above one bit of thread.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: And you let them a few pins?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not; there was a pincuſhtion on the ground, I might ſtick a few of thoſe pins.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you on the light or dark ſide after this apparatus was got ready?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: On the dark ſide. Lord Baltimore was acting the old man part of the time, and another part be came and fat by me.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you fit upon my knee?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you pledge your credit upon it, that you did not ſit upon my knee, and did not kiſs me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Kiſs him! no that I did not. Lord Baltimore came and crowded himſelf in the ſame chair where I ſat, that was all; I did not ſit on his lap.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Perhaps I was upon your knee!

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not the cords break, and the ſheets tumble upon the ground, after the company had taken ſo much pains?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe notwithſtanding the misfortunes you were ſo much depreſſed with, you laughed very heartily at it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I might laugh, but I did not laugh heartily, that I know.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Will you ſay you did not laugh heartily at it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't ſay I did not, I don't know that I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You was on the right ſide to ſee the exhibition?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it not amuſing?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I thought it an amuſement beneath gentlemen of ſenſe to employ themſelves in.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you laugh at that time?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, Sir, very little.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you walk with Mrs. Forreſt about the houſe, and have ſome converſation with her?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I had none.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you recollect her aſking you how long you had been in this family?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: She aſked me no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you tell her how long you had been in the family?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you tell her you had been a twelvemonth in my houſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Upon my oath, I ſaid no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe you complained to her that you had come down without a ſufficient number of clean things?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Mrs. Harvey told her ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you all dine together, and then come to town together that afternoon?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, we did in different carriages.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: During the time theſe people were there, did you betray by your manner or countenance that any thing extraordinary had happened to you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not; I ſupported myſelf as well as I could.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe you told us that Mrs Harvey returned to her own houſe ſoon after you returned to London?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I do not know when ſhe went away; I ſaw no more of her after Friday.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You have given an account of your being introduced to the governeſs of the young ladies; did you conſider it as an innocent thing then, to impoſe upon theſe young ladies?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not preſent myſelf to the governeſs as one come out of the country, but I did not contradict what he ſaid, becauſe he promiſed in a few days I ſhould ſee my father.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was not there a bed ordered to be put up for you in Madam Saunier's apartment?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you never underſtand ſo?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not upon that day, on Saturday, when Mrs. Griffinburg ſaid that I muſt lie in the garret.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where does Mrs. Saunier lie?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In the garret.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it in that garret you was to lie?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not in that garret.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you underſtand you was to lie in the garret Mrs. Saunier lay in?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not while I was there; ſhe lay on the ſame ſtory, but not in that room.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You did not chaſe to lie there?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not, I was afraid.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You lay with me that night. I underſtood this going to bed with me was one of the things; you certainly would not ſubmit to: how came you to make no reſiſtance?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I told him I would not go with him, but I knew he would uſe force if I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time did you get up next morning?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't know: this was on Friday.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: There was a 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: That was on Saturday.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I 〈◊〉 you had 〈◊〉 with her!

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, none but what I told you.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You entered into the general converſation that was going forward!

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You did not, though ſhe was a viſiter to them?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How came you not?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I thought my Lord and all his company were alike, except the young ladies.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you recollect the muſic maſter's being there, and I and you pulling one another; I pulling you towards me, and you drawing me to you—ſome familiarity of that kind?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, he was then come to tell me the news of my father: he took hold of my handkerchief, which I took from him again.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then you was not anxious when the gown was made, or whether it ever was to be made?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Not the leaſt in the world.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then as to giving directions how it ſhould be made, the cut of the ſleeve, and all ſuch things, you did not concern yourſelf about?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Not was in a hurry to have it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I was not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Whether you did not preſs the mantua-maker to take care of all things, that you had it next day at dinner!

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: As you ſaid it was a thing ſo indifferent to you, you muſt know whether you gave ſuch orders or no?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not; Griffinburg ordered the woman to make the gown next day by dinner, but I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you know the name of the milliner!

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did not then, but I do now.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Have you not ſome reaſon to know it now? Don't you know that that milliner has been applied to, and told if ſhe comes here ſhe ſhall loſe lier buſineſs?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I know of no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray what had you of her?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: A cap and cloak. There were more things brought; I did not take them: there were more things ordered by Mrs. Griffinburg's deſire?

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What were they!

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: A mnſlin apron and under-petticoats.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How many?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Two under petticoats.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you mean to ſwear they were ordered by her and not by you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: She deſired I would order what I wanted.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you order them or ſhe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did not order them, to my knowledge, but Griffinburg did. I don't care to give a poſitive anſwer when I am not poſitive.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Whether you gave any particular directions how they were to be made?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't tell that I did; I did not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I would put it more home to you, that you may recollect; did not you order the miliner to make the two under-petticoats to tie before?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, upon my oath I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it the mantua-maker or yourſelf that made the apron to the gown?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: There was none that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you order an apron to the gown?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Nor ſtomacher?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: She aſked me if I would have a ſtomacher: I told her I did not care about it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you, at the time you went to Mrs. Griffinburg's, know that there was any diſturbance about you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I did not; I went to meet my father.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You was very anxious to get away from my Lord, and glad to take any opportunity?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did you go to Mrs. Griffinburg?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In a coach.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it my coach or a hackney coach?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: That I don't know.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p:
You was quick enough in pointing
out the difference between a hackney coach and gentleman's in o former caſe; I deſire you would tell now?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I looked and think I ſaw a number, but am not certain.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was there any body in the coach except yourſelf, Mrs. Griffinburg, and the child?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What age is the child of?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: About eight years old.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Mrs. Griffinburg has not got a yard with great gates before her door, has ſhe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: She got out of the coach firſt, did ſhe not.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did the child go out before you, or after you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Now you had got into the open ſtreet, why did not you get away into the firſt ſhop that was open for you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Becauſe of this; I did not know but the ſervants were there; and I did not think of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Conſider, you was hazarding every thing againſt nothing: If your father was there, ſtill you would have been ſafe if you had gone off; if your father was not there, you would have been ſafe, and yet it never occurred to you when in a public ſtreet, with no ſoul but old Mrs. Griffinburg and a child, whether that was not a time to run away. I aſk you another thing: Did not this coach ſtop two or three doors from Mrs. Griffinburg's houſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You then had to walk to her houſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, the coach went on again.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time of the day was this?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: About two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You then was in the public ſtreet, exceeding deſireous of getting away from me, and never thinking that was the time to run away.—What room did you go into at Mrs. Griffinburg's?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: A back parlour on the ground floor.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Your father was not there?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not Mrs. Griffinburg go down into the kitchen to give her orders about the dinner?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: She went down and made the door faſt after her.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I deſire to have a plain anſwer, without ſeeing ſo much of the conſequence: I deſire to know whether ſhe did not go out of the room and go down into the kitchen, and leave you and Miſs Fanny alone?

sp.speaker: Mr. Serjeant Leigh.
sp.p: She explains every queſtion you aſk her, and if you take the anſwer, you muſt let her explain it.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I believe ſhe might go once or twice. She went out two or three times; ſhe always kept the door faſt, and kept amuſing me with accounts that my father was coming.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: One would have thought ſuch a young woman as you are could have got out of the parlour into the ſtreet. How many hours did you ſtay there?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't tell how many.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore
sp.p: What part of the afternoon did you ſet out for the Crown and Magpye?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: About nine o'clock. If I had tried to eſcape from Griffinburg's I believe I could not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time did Mr. Morris the tradeſman come?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He was brought to carry the letter.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did he carry the letter?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did he not come back and tell you he could not find your father at home?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then you wrote another letter?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I did, and ſent it to my father.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: That letter was your own letter, wrote by yourſelf?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you come to the door to Mr. Morris, and give him that letter to carry to Mrs. Berry, the landlady of the houſe where your father lives? You ſpeak of the boy's leading the way into the room?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you any refreſhment.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: We had a bottle of wine.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was my body in the bar?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I cannot 〈◊〉 , my Lord had hold of my hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How far might that tavern be from your father's?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: The length of the Minories, and a little way up that ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you never been by that houſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes. I ſhould know it if I was to ſee it again.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: And then you was afraid to attempt to get away becauſe I had hold of your hand?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who brought in the wine.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: A little boy.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was any bell in the room?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: The bell was rung, and the boy went backwards and forewards.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Whether, during the time you was there, you was not more than once left with no body but the child and the neice.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No: Lord Baltimore was in the room all the time; he never went out.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe the tradeſman came back, and went back with you in the coach to Dr. Griffinburg's? did he not?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: He got out of the coach to go to Sir John Fielding's?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: So I afterwards underſtood, to ſee about Harvey.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was not his buſineſs to fetch your father to Dr. Griffinburg?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't know any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: One of Sir John Fielding's clerks came with a card, you ſaid; you did not give an anſwer to it, but put the card in my hand, and I ſaid you ſhould not go; then you deſired your father might come there. Recollect yourſelf, and tell me whether that is the account you ſtand by? You ſwore, upon receiving the card, you did not ſay, I will not go to Sir John Fielding's?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Not that I know of; I did not ſay any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Recollect yourſelf?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I cannot recollect that I ſaid I would not go.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You recollected with as great exactneſs as ever I heard a witneſs?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In giving in my evidence, I gave it in every thing as far as I could recollect.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Whether, when the card was brought to you, you did not immediately ſay, without putting it into my hand, that you would not go to Sir John's?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Can you ſay poſitively one way or other?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I think you ſay, when the coach came back again to my houſe, that there was a great mob, and you called out to them, to let them come in?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When did you firſt hear of this thing they call the Habeas Corpus?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I heard the word Habeas Corpus, when they were talking in their own language.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What did you underſtand to be the reaſon of your going to Lord Mansfield's?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I concluded that my friends were taking ſome ſtep; and that carrying me to Lord Mansfield's was ſomething done by my friends in oppoſition to Lord Baltimore; but I did not know that Lord Mansfield was a magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When you was firſt told you muſt go before Lord Mansfield, did not you ſay to me that you was ſatisfied, and would not leave me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, I never ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You ſpoke of a letter you wrote to your father upon the occaſion?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe there was ſomething remarkable in that letter?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I put a little bill in it, that my father might know it came from me.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: This letter was wrote that day before you went to Lord Mansfield: how long before you went, had you finiſhed this letter?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: It was juſt then out of my hands before. Mr. Warts came in the firſt time.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You expreſs in that letter the good treatment you have received from me, and deſire they would make no more diſturbance?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did not know what to ſay, in order that he might let it go. I wrote it by his order, in a manner contrary to my heart, becauſe I was afraid he would not otherwiſe let it go; and becauſe I was afraid my father would be afraid to come.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: So then you really and truely wrote it againſt your own ſentiments?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You have mentioned Mr. Brown's being there; was it before Mr. Watts, or after?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Before.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Before the firſt time?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you not writing a letter before Mr. Srown came?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you any converſation with Mr. Brown. or me, about the habeas corpus?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: They were a talking, but I paid no regard to what they ſaid.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not Mr. Brown aſk you, whether you was of age or not?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you tell him you was more than of age conſiderably, twenty ſix?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I do not know that I ſaid ſuch a word, I do not know that Mr. Brown aſked me ſuch a queſtion?

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not Mr. Brown tell you, you was at your own liberty?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: And you did not expreſs a ſatisfaction at it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You went with Mr. Brown and me, in his carriage, did not you? did not you come to him before you finiſhed your letter, and he deſired you to go back, and finiſh it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I gave it Lord Baltimore, and he ſhewed it to Brown.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you deſired to finiſh it?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, Lord Baltimore deſired it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Mr. Brown then went out, did he not?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: That I do not know.

sp.speaker: Lood Baltimore.
sp.p: When did he return back again; before or after Mr. Watts ſerved the Habeas Corpus?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: After.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When you went to Lord Mansfield's, what did you do with your things, had not you locked them up in the garret, and got the key?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I carried away the key of the garret, but did not know that I had it, till a week afterwards.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had not you twenty guineas of me to pay for them?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, he gave me thirteen guineas on Chriſtmas Day, when I was introduced to the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I did not give you money to pay for them that morning?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You have given us an account of what paſſed before Lord Mansfield, and that he aſked you if you had not been brought to my houſe againſt your conſent, and you ſaid twice quite againſt my will; that he aſked you if you was of age, and you told him yes?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He was going to aſk me ſomething, I ſaid, I was more than of age.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you not tell my Lord Mansfield, that you knew he had no power, as you was more than of age, to oblige you to go back to your father? After having ſaid you was taken away, and detained againſt your conſent, you told Lord Mansfield, that you was willing as things were as they were, to go back to my houſe. Now, this is very myſterious, and unintelligible, that you ſhould tell this gentleman that you was brought before to be got out of my hands, that you would go back again with me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did not know what Lord Mansfield's power was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You knew your friends had brought you there, to get you out of my hands; you was with Lord Mansfield, and only another gentleman with him; have you no better reaſon to give the jury for not telling him you was unwilling to go with me again, than the not knowing Lord Mansfield's authority. Now, when you was ſent to your friends, did you immediately aſk that queſtion, was that the firſt?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I am not poſitive that that was the firſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you expreſs to your friends no ſort of inclination to go back with me.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I expreſſed an inclination, by which they found I did not know Lord Mansfield's power, and they acquainted me with it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I aſk you, if when you came to your friends, you did not expreſs an inclination to go back with me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I had no inclination to go back.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſay nothing to your friends of being deſireous to go back?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: No, nothing of your being better able to ſupply them, and provide for them?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I can't now tell what I ſaid; they found that I did not know his power.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I aſk you one more queſtion, whether you did not ſay, even to Mr. Watts, after you left Lord Mansfield's, that you was willing to go back to my houſe?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, no ſuch thing; and all my friends can teſtify the contrary.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who went to bed firſt, the laſt night you lay with me?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: In what bed?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: In Lord Baltimore's bed.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray, was any body in the room beſides me and you?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He went out.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You went into the bed, when I was not in the room.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did. He came up afterwards; Mrs. Griffinburg's neice was in the room.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: So you went and undreſſed yourſelf, and went to my bed, and I came to you.—I think you ſaid, it was on the promiſe that I ſhould not meddle with you; though you ſay I had broke that promiſe the laſt time I came to bed to you; yet you yourſelf got into my bed.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I did ſo, becauſe I was afraid he would kill me that night, if I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did you expreſs to your friends any deſire or inclination towards Lord Baltimore?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock,
sp.p: I can't tell exactly what I ſaid; they ſaid, Lord Mansfield had power to deliver me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did you, at that time, tell your father, or ſiſters, that you wanted te go back again to Lord Baltimore?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No I did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: You ſaid, Lord Baltimore had promiſed to ſend for your father in the morning.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He ſaid, it was done with a view to get my father to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What made you write ſo foreign to your heart?

sp.speaker: S Woodcock.
sp.p: Becauſe I knew he would not let it go, if it was not wrote ſo; and my father would not come, if he was not pacified.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: At the time that Lord Mansfield aſked you, if you was of age, and you told him you was—Do you recollect that he ſaid, you was at liberty to go where you pleaſed.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: He ſaid ſomething I can't tell what.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: When you went out of one room into the other, to your friends, who began the converſation firſt, you or they? Did they know, by what you had ſaid to Lord Mansfield, that you wanted to go back to Lord Baltimore's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: She had not ſeen them before; they knew not what had paſſed between her and Lord Mansfield.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Did you tell them what had paſſed between you and Lord Mansfield?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I don't remember that I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: When you found Lord Mansfield had power to ſet you at liberty, then you told them you had been violated.

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: No, not in my Lord Mansfield's houſe; As I remember, one of my ſiſters aſked me if I had been ruined, I ſaid yes:

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now with relation to ruining, that is a ſort of general term; it may be with or without your conſent. —Did you tell her whether it was without your conſent?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: She aſked, if with my conſent? I ſaid, No, without my conſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What was your reaſon of not applying to my Lord Mansfield, and afterwards applying to Juſtice Fielding?

sp.speaker: S. Woodcock.
sp.p: I was ſo overjoyed at being at liberty, that I thought of nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Do you remember a woman coming to your ſhop for a pair of ruffles?—Do you remember one Mrs. Johnſon?

sp.speaker: E. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, and Lord Baltimore followed her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Do you remember his coming ſeveral times?

sp.speaker: E. Woodcock.
sp.p: Yes, I was at home three times when Lord Baltimore came.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Was you at home when he bought ſome ribbons?

sp.speaker: E. Woodcock.
sp.p:
No, I was not then; Mrs. Harvey came on Monday the 14th of December, and deſired to know whether we had any flowered gauze; I took down the
book and ſhewed her: ſhe beſpoke a pair of double ruffles, and ordered them to be done the next day by one or two o'clock. She accordingly came, and paid for them; and ordered my ſiſter to bring ſome lace with her (to put on a child's cap) to Curtain-row where ſhe ſaid ſhe lived.
