My Lord ſaid he had no further commands for me. I came into the hall, and ſaw my Lord and the lady together. He gave orders to the coachman
to drive to Lord Mansfield's. I ſaw them go into Lord Mansfield's.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did ſhe appear?

sp.speaker: Hitchcock.
sp.p: The lady appeared very gay and ſprightly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Did Mr. Brown go in the chariot with them?

sp.speaker: Hitchcock.
sp.p: Not as I ſaw; I ſaw my Lord go into the chariot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Who handed the young lady in, my Lord? Or did ſhe go herſelf?

sp.speaker: Hitchcock.
sp.p: I ſtood with my back from the door to the fire-place.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: You ſaid my Lord Baltimore ſaid, the lady's friends might 〈◊〉 to her. Did you ſee any of her friends there!

sp.speaker: Hitchcock.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Call Dr. Griffinburg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj Leigh.
sp.p: I object to his teſtimony. He now ſtands indicted here for a conſpiracy: in abuſing this young woman, in carrying her to Lord Baltimore's: in the next place, we have here a record of the conviction of Dr. Griffinburg, for a crime of this nature, for having attempted a rape upon a girl; for which he was fined 6 s. 8 d. and impriſoned in the King's bench.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I don't care whether he is examined or not; but he is here, and I tender him that the court may not think I am afraid to examine him; if they object to his being examined, I don't preſs it.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I am a painter.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember your being in Lord Baltimore's houſe in December laſt?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p:
It was on the 17th or 18th of December laſt Lord Baltimore ſent for me. I went to his houſe; the ſervant bade me go in; I went into a yellow bow-window room, Lord Baltimore was there with a gentleman: he deſired me to ſit down; and I was to drink tea with his Lordſhip, Dr. Griffinburg, and this lady. After tea, there was a little converſation about ſeveral indifferent things; and Lord Baltimore deſired me to draw a ſketch of that lady's picture; and he gave me a black pencil. I
deſired the lady to put herſelf in a poſture to draw her picture. So ſhe did. After I had begun her picture about half an hour. I thought the lady was tired, and I deſired her to reſt. I afterwards deſired her to put herſelf in the ſame poſition, which ſhe did. After I had finiſhed it, I put it in Lord Baltimore's hand; ſhe ſmiled at it; and the converſation went on till ſupper was ready: and then Lord Baltimore deſired me to ſtay to ſupper with him. There was my Lord, this lady, Dr. Griffinburg, and another lady, that ſupped with us, I took particular notice of this lady, ſhe being a ſtranger to me: ſhe eat a bit of fowl, and ſeveral other things, and drank to every body's health; and I did the ſame as every body does. After ſupper I went home.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: As you took this lady's face, you will be able to tell us, whether it was a chearful face, or whether in tears?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: She never cried all the time. No, a figure that would cry would not ſtand in that poſition, and I could not go on. She was very willing to ſtay in that poſition. She was drawn in this poſition (deſcribing it.) leaning her head upon her hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was there any appearance of concern or ſorrow about her?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: She was rather chearful • ſhe behaved with the ſame eaſe that every body did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: She ſaid ſomething of your having carried a letter?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: That was a letter I received from a gentleman a fortnight before; who ſent me a letter to ſend to Lord Baltimore; which I did: and that day the gentleman had been to me, and ſaid he deſired to ſpeak to his Lordſhip, but he would not go to his houſe: and he deſired me to let him know; it was a tall gentleman in a brown coat.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How came he to find you out?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Lord Baltimore told me a gentleman ſhould come to me.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did this lady ſay any thing to you about your having brought any letter from her father or friends?

sp.speaker: Smith,
sp.p: No; this lady in converſation aſked what this gentleman was. I told her he was dreſt in a brown coat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Smith, your account is a pretty ſtrange one; you have been acquainted with Lord Baltimore a good while, have you not?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Next May, ſix years, I have had the honour to know his Lordſhip; and have had the honour to work for his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What day of the month was this you drew the lady's picture?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: It was on the 17th or 18th of December laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What brought you to Lord Baltimore's houſe that day?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Upon that day he ſent for me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did he let you know what he wanted you for?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I thought he had ſent for me to draw a picture: and I afterwards ſaw the truth of it. His Lordſhip ſent often for me to draw pictures.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: And yet when you came there Lord Baltimore lent you his pencil?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: When I was there I told him I had not got a pencil in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: So then you was ſent for to draw a picture and yet you went without your materials: how came you, to be in ſuch a hurry?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: He ſent to me to come directly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: And ſo you was in ſuch a hurry that you left your pencil in the other pocket?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: That is natural for people when they change their clo • ths.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What not to take the things out of their pocket?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: The ſervant told me my Lord Baltimore wanted to ſee me directly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Well, and then you ſaid, you thought that he was in a hurry; and you went and left theſe materials at home: that is the fact, I think. Now when you came to Lord Baltimore's there was ſome converſation paſſed relating to a letter. Tell my Lord and the jury what the letter was he aſked you about.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: The letter I had wrote to my Lord from a gentleman that had been with me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What gentleman was he?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: How did he ſend it you?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: My Lord told me that ſuch a gentleman ſhould come to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Now ſee if I underſtand you. A fortnight before this my Lord told you, that a gentleman ſhould come to you; but he did not come, but ſent you a letter. Did you ſend that letter?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I ſent it to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Then it was a letter directed to your hands —to be given to Lord Baltimore; and this you was informed of a fortnight before?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: This gentleman came juſt that day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: And this was the very day the man came with the meſſage to Lord Baltimore, and juſt before that this letter was brought to you?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No, this letter was brought a fortnight before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: When was it delivered to Lord Baltimore?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: The inſtant I had received it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Then had you any further directions in it?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No, that gentleman called upon me on that very day, about four or five o'clock in the evening.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: What did he ſay to you?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: He ſaid, that he wanted to ſpeak to his Lordſhip. I aſked if he would go to his Lordſhip? He ſaid, he would not go, but deſired me to let my Lord know he had been with me; and ſo I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did you do it by meſſage, or go to his houſe?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I ſent a letter in French, that a gentleman that I did not know had been at my houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Now all this happened before you went to my Lord the ſame day, and yet you thought it was all about drawing a picture?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: My Lord aſked me what ſort of a man he was? And the lady aſked me what was the colour of his coat? I ſaid, a brown coat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Was that the only queſtion ſhe aſked you?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Only then about the colour of the coat the man had on that called upon you that day. She ſaid nothing about the ſize of the man, whether taller or ſhorter, did ſhe?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Not a ſingle word.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: And this was in conſquence of a letter that was ſent a fortnight before. What is your name?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: My name is Smith.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I live in Dufour's Court, Broad-ſtreet Carnaby market.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: What converſation had you at Lord Baltimore's that day about this man in the brown coat?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: My Lord aſked me whether he was an old or a young man? I ſaid, an old man in a brown coat.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Now was it an old man in a brown coat?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes, and a very tall man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did he aſk you that queſtion in the preſence of the lady, or behind her back, in French or Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No, in plain Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did my Lord ſay any thing to you in French?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes he did ſpeak ſome words in French, ſomething relating to what had paſſed in the news papers.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What is the buſineſs you generally do for me?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I take deſigns for my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You being a foreigner, do not I often talk to you in your own language?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr Cox.
sp.p: You ſay you was preſent when the lady drank tea, will you, upon your oath, ſay you ſaw her drink one drop of tea?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: She was very merry in converſation as the reſt were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: You was there at ſupper; Did ſhe drink every body's health?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: She drank my Lord's health, and ſhe drank to every body round.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: In what liquor?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I believe ſmall beer.
I am Lord Baltimore's laundry-maid. I was at Lord Baltimore's houſe in December; I was there before they went to Woodcote.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you know in what bed Mrs. Harvey uſed to lie?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: In the next room to my Lord's bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore
sp.p: I would aſk you, if you know any perſon that lay with her there?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe Sarah Woodcock did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was there the appearance of two perſons in Mrs Harvey's bed?

sp.speaker: Hariſon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who made the fire in this room?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee any people in bed together in that room?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I have ſeen Mrs. Harvey and Miſs Woodcock in bed together, I cannot ſay how often; I have ſeen them every morning in bed till the went to Woodcote, all but the firſt morning after ſhe came. I have heard them converſe there.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I would aſk you whether you ever ſaw any acts of civility between Mrs. Harvey ands Miſ Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I have always ſeen her very merry.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſee her perpetually in tears, lamenting and pining?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: No, never; I always ſaw her laughing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you often ſee her in the day-time?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I did: Mrs. Harvey uſed to dreſs her.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: And what did ſhe uſe to do for her?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I have only ſeen her comb her hair, I ſaw her do that twice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Who is this Mrs. Harvey? Did ſhe live in this houſe? Did ſhe lie there before this girl came?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: No ſhe did not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Then they came together?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Baker.
sp.p: You went to make the fire the firſt morning, where was the girl?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: She was in the room with Mrs. Harvey: they were both up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Where was Mrs. Griffinburg?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: In the room too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: I aſk you upon your oath, was not Griffinburg in the room the next night?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: No, ſhe was not. On Thurſday night and Wedneſday night ſhe lay below ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: So in the morning before you went to make the fire, Mrs. Griffinbugh had got up ſtairs, and was in the room with them?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: She went up to ſhew me the room. I had been there almoſt a twelvemonth, but did not know they were there; Mrs. Griffinburg told me I was to go in that way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p:
If I underſtand you right, you told me
you found there the two priſoners and Miſs Woodcock. Pray did Dr. Griffinburg lie in this houſe!

sp.speaker: Harriſon
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Pray what was Mrs. Griffinburg in this houſe?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Houſekeeper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Pray did the young woman bring any cloths into the houſe?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: When did the change her cloths?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: After the came from Woodcote.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Did the bring any linen with her?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: When was the firſt time ſhe had any clean linen?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I can't ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Who did the have it of?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Mrs. Griffinburg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Now I aſk you if that was not the Monday morning, the day ſhe went to Woodcote?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: I can't ſay the day when it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: The girl was always a laughing, conſtantly, was ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: What, whether you ſpoke to her or not? Did ſhe walk all about the houſe?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw her in my Lord's bedchamber the Friday before ſhe went to Woodcote.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: What, never go out all the time?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: No, not that I know of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: What, did ſhe ſhut up herſelf in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: She might have gone out if ſhe would.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Then you don't know the reaſon of Mrs Harvey's ſtaying in the houſe at this particular time? You don't know where ſhe liv'd?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not Griffinburg go up with you into the room?

sp.speaker: Harriſon.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe did; and was giving me directions where to light the fire.
I am cook to Lord Baltimore.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray what apartment did you lie in?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: Over the room in which my Lord lay.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where did Mrs. Harvey lie?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: In the ſame room Miſs Woodcock lay in: my room is partly over my Lord's room, and partly over Mrs. Harvey's.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray have you ever heard any converſation, or noiſe?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: I have heard laughing, talking, and merriment.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then you heard it often?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What when Miſs Woodcock has been there?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ever hear any noiſe or crying out?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: This was in London?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: Yes, in London: all that I heard was merriment and laughing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Miſs Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: No; but I know ſhe was there. I could diſtinguiſh three voices.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: You ſay that if there had been any crying out, or noiſe below, you muſt have heard it?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: I am ſure of that; I have heard laughing and talking, but never heard any crying out: I could hear every thing that mov'd or ſtirr'd.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Can you hear the curtains draw?

sp.speaker: Mitchell.
sp.p: I could; I could have diſtinguiſhed voices in the room; or if any body was to ſpeak or ſtir the fire, I could hear it.
I am one of Lord Baltimore's poſtilions.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you one of the drivers when I went to Woodcote?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: Yes; I drove the wheel-horſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who was in the carriage?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p:
There was Dr. Griffinburg, his wife, my Lord, and two women more; I took notice of the people
that went into the carriage; they went in very chearfully; I obſerved nothing in particular; it was a poſt coach with four horſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What glaſſes are there?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: There are ſore glaſſes and ſide glaſſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Can you tell which way we ſat?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: His Lordſhip and two women ſat together; they rode with their faces to the horſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was there not a little accident happened at ſetting out?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: The porter forgot to faſten one part of the gate; the wind blew the gate to, and the hind wheel laid hold of it: I expected the carriage was torn all to pieces, but I found it was the gate, and as ſoon as I could ſtop the carriage, I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How long did you ſtop?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: For about a minute or two; there was a great many people got round the carriage; the glaſſes were up.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Upon the accident happening, were they not let down?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: One of the ſide glaſſes was; we went on to Woodcote, over Weſtminſter bridge, at the uſual rate.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you no particular orders to hurry?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Could you, who was the neareſt poſtilion, hear the voices of the people in the carriage as you went along?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: I heard a good deal of mirth and merriment, langhing, and ſo on; they ſeemed all very chearful: they arrived at Woodcote between two and three o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time did you ſet out?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: A little after eleven.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you ſpeak with certainty as to the time?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: Not to a moment; I ſpeak to the beſt of my knowledge, I ſaw his Lordſhip get out of the coach, and this Brange woman gave him her hand, and he led her in.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe look as if ſhe was a priſoner?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſee them afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: No, I went to take care of my horſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you not wait at table?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: I never waited at his Lordſhip's table. They came back again in the ſame manner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: What was it o'clock?

sp.speaker: Mackdonald.
sp.p: Not more than three. It was more than full day-light.
I am one of Lord Baltimore's footmen.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember going to Woodcote?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who went there, and in what manner?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: It was my Lord's own poſt coach and four • there was my Lord, Dr. Griffinburg, Mrs. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey, and Miſs Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time did you ſet out from London?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: At about half an hour after eleven or thereabout.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember any accident that happened as you were coming out, with one of the gates?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: The wind blew it to; it was very near overturning; that it cauſed a ſtoppage for about a couple of minutes, and a great many people were paſſing and repaſſing. I went behind the coach to Woodcote.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray which way did the coach go out of town?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: It went over Weſtminſter bridge.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Perhaps as you was behind, you can tell the behaviour of the company?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I frequently heard the company langhing, and very merry.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was either of the glaſſes let down?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: The near glaſs was let down when the accident happen'd at the gate.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then you went the whole journey behind the coach.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you hear laughing at different times?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I did, when I was behind the coach.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who went in firſt?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I think Sarah Woodcock; ſhe got in by herſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When 〈◊〉 came to Woodcote, do you remember how they go • out?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I opened the coach door, and his Lordſhip got out firſt, and then Sarah Woodcock: his Lordſhip, I believe, offered his hand, and ſhe leaned her hand upon his arm; I am not certain: then all the company went up the ſlight of ſteps into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where did you go to?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Into his Lordſhip's parlour.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you wait at dinner?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who ſat at dinner that day?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: His Lordſhip, Dr. and Mrs. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey and Sarah Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe eat any thing at dinner?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe drink any thing?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes—Wine and water.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe behave, or not, as the reſt of the company did?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I could ſee no manner of difference.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe appear in diſtreſs then ſhe got out of the coach at Woodcore? Did you ſee her at any time crying, and in diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you not upon the water?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who was there?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: His Lordſhip, Mrs. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey, and Sarah Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who conducted the boat?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: His Lordſhip and I rowed it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember the day that ſome company came down?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes; it was Wedneſday the 23d. They came after dinner: Sarah Woodcock drank tea with the reſt of the company: I waited at table: Mr. Smith was one.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What, Smith the painter?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: No, a Ge • man, and a gentleman and lady beſides, whoſe names I did not know •

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe behave at tea as the reſt of the company did?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes; I did not ſee the leaſt ſign of diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe cut and drink at ſupper?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: She did; ſhe generally drank wine and water.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe next day we went to town!

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes they did; I went to town on horſeback.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: We ſupped there on Wedneſday, did we not? Where did the company breakfaſt?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: They breakfaſted in the parlour; Miſs Woodcock was there.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How was the time taken up?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I don't know. They walked about the park when they had a mind, and came into the houſe when they had a mind, and when they pleaſed. On Tueſday morning after breakfaſt, they went upon the water.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did Miſs Woodcock breakfaſt on Tueſday morning with the family?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Yes. I remember ſeeing them get into the carriage.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember how they got into the coach?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: Sarah Woodcock got in firſt, and had no aſſiſtance, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you near enough the carriage to ſee the behaviour of the people in the inſide of it?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: No; I was on horſeback as I returned.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: During the time ſhe was in town, or at Woodcote, did you ever ſee her in tears?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I never did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Were there any doors locked, or the like?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: No, the doors were all open.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Were there any directions given to the ſervants to ſtop her, in cafe the went out?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: No, not by Lord Baltimore or any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you at Lord Mansfields? I only aſk you to one particular fact; did you ſee any little intimacy between any body after the thing was over?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: A young man laid hold of her by the arm, and juſt as they got down to the ſecond ſtep, he kiſſed her.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did ſhe behave?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I ſtood at the bottom of the ſteps.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who was the man that kiſs'd her!

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: They told me his name was Davis.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who 〈…〉 ſpoke, or looked, 〈◊〉 did any thing to you?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p:
When the 〈…〉 down 〈…〉 by m • , the 〈…〉 and looked me •
〈…〉 and ſmiled at me,

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: You ſay ſhe got firſt into the coach, did you know her.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: I have ſeen her perſon. I ſaw her looking out at the window, but I never waited on her in London. I waited at table at breakfaſt, dinner and ſupper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: You are employed to wait at table, and yet you ſay you never ſaw this girl but at Lord Baltimore's window: This was ſevere weather, had you been uſed to parties of pleaſure on the water in ſuch ſevere weather?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What fort of a veſſel is this?

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.p: A large boat. My Lord has built a fort of a cabin in one of them. The firſt day they were in the open boat, and in the cabin the ſecond day.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Perry.
sp.p: I live in Fore-ſtreet, St. Giles's, Cripplegate. I was at Lord Baltimore's on the 21ſt of December laſt; I was going to Dr. Griffinburg to recommend a friend of mine to him: when we came to Dr. Griffinburg's houſe, I went from thence to my Lord Baltimore's, and when Mrs. Vergen my friend and I came within about ten yards of the porter's lodge, the coach came out with four bay horſes; the coach took part of the gate away; the coach ſtopt ſome little time; I was pretty near the coach; I ſaw five people in it; I ſaw Dr. Griffinburg in the coach, and pulled of my hat to him, and wiſhed him a good ride, I ſaw my Lord and the other woman, I do'nt mean the young woman.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you hear any call for aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Perry.
sp.p: There was a great number of people, ten or a dozen, paſſing and repaſſing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you wonder that nobody called out?

sp.speaker: Perry.
sp.p: I was ſurpriſed, that from the danger the coach was in, that nobody ſcreamed out that was in the coach.

div.p:
I was at Lord Baltimore's on the 21ſt of December laſt, and ſaw an accident with the coach, it ran againſt the gate, and ſtopt about a minute; I looked into the
coach, there were five people in it; I did not hear any body call out in it.

sp.speaker: Lord Batilmore.
sp.p: Were there any other people there?

sp.speaker: Vergen.
sp.p: Yes, ſeveral; I was near the coach, ſo near that if any body had ſpoke I ſhould have heard them.
I am a butler (in the country) to my Lord Baltimore.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember the coach coming to Woodcote?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who were in it?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: Lord Baltimore, Dr. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey, and Miſs Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who opened the coach door?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: The footman that came down with it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember their geting out of the coach?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: I don't know who handed her out; they went up the lawn into the parlour; my Lord came back on the lawn, and Miſs Woodcock came after him; ſhe got hold of his arm and run into the houſe; that was before dinner; and ſhe ſat down to dinner, and always drank firſt his Lordſhip's health; ſhe drank tea, and was very merry and chearful. I attended his Lordſhip in his bedchamber; I warmed his bed and undreſſed him; Dr. Griffinburg came in; I heard the other door open, but who opened it I don't know.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing ſaid upon that occaſion?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: Dr. Griffinburg was in his Lordſhip's room, and went round to the door.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing in the other room, of any noiſe, or outcry, or complaint?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: No. On Tueſday morning I ſaid the cloth for breakfaſt; Mrs Harvey and Miſs Woodcock came down together; they were very merry and chearful.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Were there any marks of deep diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: Not any.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore
sp.p: Could you have then conceived by her appearance ſhe had been raviſhed the night before?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p:
No; the always had co • ee between twelve and one o'clock; on Tueſday morning I ſaw Mrs. Griffinburg and Miſs Woodcock come out of the room; ſhe ran down the • airs after her; ſhe jumped down and
catched hold of Mrs. Griffinburg's arm, 〈…〉 little piece of water, and was very merry.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Some company came on Wedneſday, did they not?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember the entertainment of that evening?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: It was a kind of magic lanthorn; and Miſs Woodcock, for one, downed on her knees upon the carpet, ſewing theſe table-cloaths together, to make one piece of it, and ſhe laughed at it, and was extremely merry about it, more ſo than any one: the cord broke, and we were obliged to put it up again; Miſs Woodcock laughed very much at that, more particularly than any body; ſhe came into my pantry one day, and admired the paintings there.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was there any orders given for reſtraining her?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: No, I never ſaw her but ſhe had her liberty to go where ſhe pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Were there not ſeveral workmen about?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: There were forty or fifty workmen about the houſe and park: ſhe might have gone away, I dare ſay, if ſhe choſe it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: You know Mrs. Harvey; was ſhe ever at Woodcote before this?

sp.speaker: Stanger.
sp.p: No. Miſs Woodcock was the merrieſt always, ſhe laughed ſurpriſingly, and was always the merrieſt of the company.

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: I am land ſteward to Lord Baltimore.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember my coming down on the 21ſt of December to Woodcote?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: I ſaw my Lord's carriage coming, but I did not ſee him get out; he ſtaid to the 24th; there was a young lady with him, one Miſs Woodcock; I remember to have ſeen her there very well; 〈◊〉 once ſaw her with Mrs. Griffinburg a furlong, at leaſt, from the houſe in the park; the next time I ſaw her along with Mrs. Harvey and Mrs. Griffinbu • gh, and they walked down to the bottom of the lawn, and turned round the pa • es at the bottom.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you any workmen employed then?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: Yes; I believe we had ten men at work on the outſide, and ten on the inſide of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did they walk near where theſe men were?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: They walked ſo nigh that they could talk to the workmen.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing of ſome Italian ſhades repreſented there one night?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: Yes; I do; they were ſewed together; I was not preſent at the time they were ſewing; I put them up; when I was drawing it up, the rope broke, and it dropt; Miſs Woodcock laughed very heartily, and the lady that ſat next to her. I was coming out of the great room that evening, and ſaw Miſs Woodcock warming her feet in a room by herſelf; that was on Wedneſday night the 23d,

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſee her often when ſhe was down?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: I ſaw her many times, and ſhe ſeemed to be very chearful and eaſy.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ever hear of any orders given to confine her?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: No, none at all.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Could ſhe not have gone out of the houſe as well as any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: That ſeat is not far from Epſom?

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.p: About a mile we call it; it is but half a mile from our park.

div.p: I live at Woodcote; I am my Lord's houſe-maid at Woodcote; I remember Miſs Woodcock being there; I was there all the time ſhe was there.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did ſhe behave?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: Very well; the ſame as the reſt of the ladies

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was ſhe dejected, or in good ſpirits?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: I obſerved no difference; ſhe was under no reſtraint; I ſaw her on the lawn on the Monday, the day ſhe came.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who was walking with her?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: His Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Before or after dinner?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: Before dinner, as ſoon as they came down.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: In what manner did ſhe walk with him?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: She was cloſe by him; I did not obſerve whether ſhe had held of him or not, but ſhe ſeemed very merry and chearful.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You warmed the beds there I believe?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Whoſe bed did you warm?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: I warmed the bed for Mrs. Harvey and Miſs Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you warm the bed on Tueſday night!

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who were there?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: Doctor Griffinburg, his wife, Mrs. Harvey, and Miſs Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any thing?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: They were all very merry.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did they laugh as if it was ſomething ſudden?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: I can't ſay what they were ſo merry about.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Mrs. Harvey there before?

sp.speaker: Chandler.
sp.p: No, never.

div.p: I am his Lordſhip's cook at Woodcote: I was confined to my bed on account of an accident I had; I was viſited on Wedneſday the 23d of December.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you know by whom?

sp.speaker: Greenoch.
sp.p: One Miſs Woodcock came in with Doctor Griffinburg.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: In what manner did ſhe appear?

sp.speaker: Greenoch.
sp.p: Very chearful.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did the appear in any diſtreſs of mind?

sp.speaker: Greenoch.
sp.p: No; ſhe ſaid mine was a very great misfortune; then ſhe ſaid to Dr. Griffinburg, Sir, will you take a walk; the Doctor ſaid he would; ſhe went out and put her hat on, and came into my room; then the Doctor and ſhe went out to take a walk.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I am a merchant: I have been acquainted with Lord Baltimore; I have known him about eight years; I was one of the party that made Lord Baltimore a viſit at Woodcote.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who were the party?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: There was Captain Pezer; a gentleman; and there was a young lady with us.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Under whoſe protection was ſhe?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Under mine. We came there about five o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What day was it?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I believe on Wedneſday the 23d of December: when we went up ſtairs I found my Lord, Mrs. Griffinburg, and Dr. Griffinburg, Mrs. Harvey, and Miſs Woodcock, all at tea.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not ſome amuſement go forward in the evening?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord propoſed to make a ſhade.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did Miſs Woodcock lend a hand to this!

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes; firſt ſhe pinned them, and afterwards took needle and thread and joined them.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: While theſe ſhades went on, where was ſhe? after ſhe had done her work, what became of Miſs Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: I ſaw them ſtanding there all together; I went behind to perform, becauſe we did not perform at a time; I was a performer, and Mr. Pezer, and a little black boy.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſee any more there?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p:
While this exhibition was going forward, and almoſt over, my Lord and I came from behind the curtain; my Lord went on, and I ſtopt at the chimney at the corner: I believe he went up to the ladies; I ſaw my Lord in a moment afterwards, ſitting in an elbowchair; Miſs Woodcock came after him; my Lord ſat down in the elbow-chair, and Miſs Woodcock ſat down upon his knee, with her arm upon his neck, not quite round his neck, rather upon his ſhoulder: I then obſerved my Lord kiſſed her, and he drew back, and ſhe kiſſed him, I ſaw it plain: after this we went to ſupper, and I ſaw Miſs Woodcock ſit next to Miſs Forreſt, and ſhe was ſitting next my Lord, and ſhe ſeemed to be very chearful and in good ſpirits; I obſerved one thing more, ſhe poured out a glaſs of wine for Miſs Forreſt, and one for herſelf, and they drank to my Lord and the company;
after ſupper was over, they wiſhed us a good night. Next morning the ladies were not below when I came down; my Lord was already below, and Mr. Pezer; then the ladies came in ſucceſſively, and they ſat down to breakfaſt; I went to take a walk with my Lord; afterwards I came back and found the ladies ſitting in the room; I ſaw particularly Miſs Woodcock and Miſs Forreſt running upon the terras, ſeemingly in high ſpirits and chearful; the other ladies walked behind.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: During the time you was there, was the lady under any conſtraint, uneaſineſs, or concern?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Could you obſerve ſhe laboured under any private uneaſineſs and grief?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No, not to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, where do you live in London?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: In Newman-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You are guardian to Miſs Forreſt?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I thought you ſaid ſhe was under your protection.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: She is my houſekeeper.
I was one of the three people that went to viſit Lord Baltimore; I went down with the laſt witneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who went down in your party?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: Mr. Smith, and Miſs Forreſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What day did you go down?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: On Wedneſday the 23d of December.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When you came there, how was my Lord engaged?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: He was in the room with Mrs. Harvey and Miſs Woodcock; they were drinking tea.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did you amuſe yourſelves in the evening?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: My Lord darkened part of the room; on the the other ſide was placed a candle; I myſelf and others played there.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember who aſſiſted in joining the cloths together?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: The • dies did, Miſs Woodcock and the others; the cords broke and it ſell down.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did that create any laughter?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: May be it did; I did not obſerve theſe things.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember who ſupped there!

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Miſs Woodcock was one of the party; was ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe refrain from drinking?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: No, ſhe eat and drank as all the reſt did; I took a bottle and ſaid, You have no wine, ladies: and I poured them out wine; there was a hare froze in the ice, and they ran down to ſee it, and they ran up again; Miſs Woodcock was one of them, upon honour.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any appearance of gloom in her countenance?

sp.speaker: Pezer.
sp.p: No, not the leaſt, or diſcontent; ſhe appeared as the reſt of the company.
I am houſekeeper to Mr. Smith; I was at Lord Baltimore's with theſe two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time was that?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: It was the 23d.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Of what month?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it before Chriſtmas?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſee me there, and Miſs Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time did you go there?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: About five in the evening. I ſaw there my Lord, Mrs. Harvey, Miſs Woodcock, Dr. Griffinburg, and Mrs. Griffinburg.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What were they doing together?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Drinking tea.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was Miſs Woodcock drinking tea with them?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes: I joined company.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was you left alone with Miſs Woodcock any time!

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember any pictures?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember my taking a walk?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: No; I do not remember it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing about the pictures?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: She (Miſs Woodcock) got a candle, and looked at the pictures, and ſhewed them me.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe then appear dejected?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: No; ſhe was as merry as the merrieſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember the magic lanthorn?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes; there was ſomething of that ſort; I don't know what you call it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe join in the company that night?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes; ſhe was as much diverted as the merrieſt; ſhe laughed; I lent her my pincuſhion; ſhe helped to pin them; and when the needles and thread came up, ſhe helped to ſew, ſhe was as much pleaſed as any of the reſt; ſhe appeared to me to have the ſame liberty as the reſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who ſupped with you?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: We all ſupped together.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did Miſs Woodcock eat any ſupper?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes; ſhe eat the ſame, and as hearty as the reſt; the laughed, and was as merry as the reſt. As ſoon as ſupper was over, the women all got up together, and bid his Lordſhip a good night. As the four women retired after ſupper, we were going through a gallery, I ſaid, there are a great many doors. She ſaid, Yes; and if I would go with her, ſhe would ſhew me my Lord's bed-room. I went in with her.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you any converſation upon that occaſion? Did any thing more paſs that night?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: No nothing at all.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What paſſed next morning?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Us women joined together to breakfaſt: the gentlemen had breakfaſted before, except Dr. Griffinburg; he ſat down to breakfaſt with us; Miſs Woodcock breakfaſted with us.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: That was on Thurſay morning, I believe?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes it was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe eat any breakfaſt?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p:
Yes, as much as the reſt. After breakfaſt we walked up the terras; we talked with Miſs Woodcock; at breakfaſt ſhe ſaid ſhe was aſhamed of her linen; that if ſhe had thought of his Lordſhip's ſtaying ſo long down there, ſhe would have provided herſelf with linen.
When we were walking upon the terras, ſhe told me, ſhe had never been there before, but had lived in my Lord's family above a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you walk out that morning?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: It was a very cold morning, and ſhe and I ran ſeveral times on the terras by way of diverſion. As ſoon as I came in again, I lent her a ſhift, an apron, and a pair of ruffles. I went into my own room, (the room I lay in.)

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you any converſation with Miſs Woodcock at that time?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: She was not in my room at that time.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What did ſhe tell you there?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: I don't remember. After I had brought up the linen into her room, ſhe told me not to make myſelf uneaſy; for as ſoon as ſhe got home to his Lordſhip's houſe, ſhe would ſend the linen by one of the ſervants.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: So ſhe looked upon my houſe as her own home?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe eat and drink there at that time?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe did, and poured herſelf out a glaſs of wine, and poured out ſome for me too.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe drink to any body?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes; ſhe drank Lord Baltimore's health.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe appear to be in a dejected ſtate, or did ſhe appear to be a woman that was well contented with her ſituation? Did ſhe appear to be a perſon that was at liberty, or under reſtraint or confinement?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: She appeared to be at liberty as much as any body elſe; ſhe might have got away if ſhe would; ſhe was in as high ſpirits as any of the reſt; always in high ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: You ſay ſhe was juſt as chearful as any of the reſt, neither more nor leſs, but exactly as chearful that you obſerved?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: And eat and drank juſt as the reſt did exactly?

sp.speaker: Forreſt:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Did you make that obſervation at that time?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: No, not a particular obſervation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: When did you firſt make the obſervation?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: When we were at ſupper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: That was that time?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: No; this is the next day.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: How came you to think of it?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: Upon what occaſion did ſhe tell you ſhe had been there a twelvemouth?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: As we were coming off from the terras, I aſked her if ſhe had ever been down there before; ſhe ſaid No; but ſhe had lived in his Lordſhip's family above a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How long have you lived with Mr. Smith, and in what capacity?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: I have been his houſekeeper this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Where did you come from to him?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: From Nottinghamſhire.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Who did you live with there?

sp.speaker: Forreſt.
sp.p: I came from my father.
I work for Lord Baltimore at Woodcote, as a carpenter.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember my coming down in my carriage there?

sp.speaker: Walter.
sp.p: Yes, I do. His Lordſhip came with three ladies and a gentleman; I knew Mrs. Griffinburg; there were two young ones, whoſe names I did not know; I have ſince heard who they were.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What are their names?

sp.speaker: Walter.
sp.p: Mrs. Harvey and Sarah Woodcock. I ſaw one lady get out, and my Lord followed her: ſhe appeared very agreeable and loving: I ſaw her again on Tueſday walking in the park; Mrs. Griffinburg was with her; ſhe appeared very gay: ſhe was arm in arm with Mrs. Griffinburg; I ſaw her walking about at other times while there; ſhe always appeared gay and chearful; ſhe ſeemed to be at liberty to go where ſhe pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: Was not ſomebody always with her?

sp.speaker: Walter.
sp.p: Yes, I believe there was.
I am governeſs to my Lord's daughters; one of them is ſince dead.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, when did you firſt ſee this lady?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: On Chriſtmas-day ſhe was introduced with her hat, cloak, and gloves on.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: As what?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: A companion to the miſſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was ſhe introduced by my Lord?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: He ſaid it was a perſon very well rocommended by her father to be a companion to the miſſes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What ſaid ſhe to this?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: She made no reply.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: In what way did ſhe live in the family while ſhe ſtaid there?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: She eat and drank with me and the ladies, my Lord's daughters, as chearful as any body; ſhe breakfaſted, dined, and ſupped with Madam Saunier and the family.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What was ſhe employed in?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Sometimes working: on Saturday evening ſhe was at work, and ſeveral parts of the day.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had my Lord and ſhe any converſation?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: They had upon Chriſtmas evening.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What was their ſubject?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Many ſubjects; they were talking of ſcripture.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What were they talking of?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: They were talking of Paul, and Saul, and Iſaiah, and Adam and Eve.—Miſs Woodcock ſaid Adam was created upright; at which we all laughed.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray did ſhe join in that laugh?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray do you remember Mrs. Pynſon's coming to ſee the ladies?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: She dined and ſupped with you I think?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How was ſhe employed that day?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: That was on Saturday; ſhe was making gauze ruffles and aprons.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was any thing ſaid about her playing at cards that evening?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You had opportunities of couverſing with her, and ſometimes, I ſuppoſe, alone?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: I was with her many times alone.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Could you diſcover, from the ſtile of her converſation, that ſhe was uneaſy, and detained againſt her will, or any ſecret diſcontent?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: No, not in the leaſt; nor did I know to the contrary, nor who ſhe was, till the was gone.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: From the manner of her being introduted to you, with her hat and cloak on, ſhe certainly aſſiſted me to impoſe upon you, or ſhe could certainly have contradicted it?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Yes, I ſuppoſe ſo.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Did ſhe not come from Woodcote that day?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: I did not know ſhe had been at Woodcote; I never heard a word of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Your apartments were diſtinct from the reſt of the family, were they not?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: There is a room where the maſters attend upon the ladies: there is a room for writing, and another for muſick, and the ladies are employed every hour of the day with one or other of the maſters.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: It is a very large houſe, is it not?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you know of her being in confinement?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Would ſhe play at cards?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: So you never knew all this time that this girl was in the houſe; you who are governeſs to his daughters and lived in the ſame houſe?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: No, I did not know ſhe was in the houſe till they came back again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Or did you ever know Mrs. Harvey was there?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Did the young ladies never eat with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p: When he has no company ſometimes they do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee Mrs. Harvey before?

sp.speaker: Dunning.
sp.p:
No, I never knew there was ſuch a woman
in the houſe till this broke out; I never ſaw Harvey or Woodcock till Chriſtmas-day.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray, did you know Miſs Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember her being at Woodcote that December?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was ſhe introduced to you at any time, and in what character?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: Yes, on Chriſt mas-day, as a companion to the young ladies.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How long was ſhe at the houſe in town?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: Three days, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Could ſhe have gone out of my houſe if ſhe thought proper? Were any orders given to the family to keep her in?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: No, ſhe was under no reſtraint; ſhe could have got out whenever ſhe pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee her in tears?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: No, ſhe was as chearful as we.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you know of her being to have a bed in your room?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: Yes, there was a bed made up there.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe ever lie in it?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: No, ſhe would not lie in it.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What ſort of a room was it?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: It was a little room; there were two beds in it; it was a good room; there was a bed made on purpoſe for her to lie in my room.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had ſhe a nightcap in your room?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: Yes, and ſhe went and fetched it out.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you hear any thing ſaid of Miſs Woodcock's application to me?

sp.speaker: Saunier.
sp.p: She refuſed to lie in that room, and ſaid ſhe would ſpeak with me firſt: I told her I ſhould ſee her again; ſhe fetched the night-cap out, and ſaid ſhe did not chooſe to lie with any body in the room.

div.p:
Lord Baltimore ſent a note with his compliments to me on the 26th of December, and that if I was not engaged,
he would ſend his coach for me. I went; I ſaw my Lord, his two daughters, Miſs Woodcock Mrs. Saunier, Mrs. Dunning, and Dr. Griffinburg; we all dined together.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did Miſs. Woodcock appear at dinner?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: Extremely chearful, and the moſt pleaſed of any perſon there.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe dine, and eat as other people did?—Did you ſtay there after dinner?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: I drank tea there and ſupped.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did you ſpend your afternoon?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: The young lady after dinner, and Miſs Juliet, got up, that is ſhe that is dead.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: I believe ſhe was about fifteen at that time.

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: Yes.—They got up, and went into the drawing-room together, both laughing, immoderately. She was chearful and gay till tea-time came on, and then they were all at work. My Lord ſaid, My ladies don't love cards: I ſaid to my Lord, the ladies are very chearful at work, (ſhe was at work on gauze); ſhe ſaid it would waſh well, and th t the apron I had on would waſh well; it had been waſhed. I aſked Mrs. Saunier how long that lady had been in the family; ſhe ſaid the day before. I obſerved ſhe was extremely chearful, and appeared as if ſhe had been in the family a twelvemonth. She and Miſs Juliet ſeemed very fond of each other.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you obſerve any diſcontent of mind?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: She appeared to me to be at her full liberty as much as I; ſhe appeared under no reſtraint.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: She did not appear to be a perſon with an afflicted mind, did ſhe? Did you ſee her cry?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: No: if laughing is crying, ſhe had ſufficient of that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Are you a married woman?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: No, I am not: I have been married.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Where do you live?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: In Warwick Court Holborn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Are you of any employment, or bufineſs?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: No, I live upon my fortune.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: You went to my Lord Baltimore's, and there were theſe people, my Lord and his two daughters, Mrs. Saunier, Mrs. Dunning, Dr. Griffinburg, and Miſs Woodcock: it ſtruck you very much, I think, that this girl was ſo very merry?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: As I had not been in the family for five months, I enquired after her.

sp.speaker: Mr, Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: So then ſhe was ſo extremely chearful, that you enquired after her on that account?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: I was going to ſay to the ladies, tell me what you laugh at, that I may laugh with you, but my Lord was there, and ſo I thought I would not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: How long did you ſtay after dinner?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: I ſupped there,

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Did the young ladies and my Lord Baltimore ſup with you?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: And were they all as chearful at night?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: But this girl ſtruck you?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: They were all chearful.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: You knew Mrs. Dunning was an inſtructor to the young ladies, and Mrs. Saunier: and yet you had not the curioſity to enquire who this young lady was?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Well then, you thought, I ſuppoſe, ſhe was brought in merely to laugh. As you took ſo much notice of this girl, I wonder your curioſity did not lead you to enquire in what capacity ſhe was in the family?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: No; my Lord was preſent; it was when Mrs. Saunier went to the fire I ſpoke to her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Well, but ſuppoſe my Lord was there, you was on a good footing; there was no great diſtance kept.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: If I underſtand you right, the reaſon why you took notice of this young woman was, becauſe you had never ſeen her there before?

sp.speaker: Pynſons.
sp.p: Yes.

div.p: I am a mantua-maker; I was ſent for to my Lord Baltimore's the 26th of December.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: For what purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: To make a gown for a young lady, whom, I ſince underſtand, is Miſs Woodcock: I made the gown.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you receive any directions from Miſs Woodcock about making the gown?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: I did. I aſked her if ſhe choſe it with an apron, or without? She ſaid, without an apron.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe chooſe what colour her gown ſhould be?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: I aſked her what I was to meaſure her for? Mrs. Griffinburg aſked, Would ſhe have a night-gown, or a negligee? She choſe a night-gown, becauſe I told her it was impoſſible to have a negligee made by next day; Mrs. Griffinburg had ſaid at firſt, you muſt have it made by to-morrow: and then ſhe choſe a night-gown. I aſked her how ſhe choſe to have it made; whether to button before, or with a looſe ſtomacher? She ſaid with a looſe ſtomacher.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was it made?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When did you bring it home?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: I came to try it on at 9 o'clock the ſame evening.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore
sp.p: Where did you find Miſs Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: At the top of the ſtairs, with a candle in her hand. I went into her bed-room; I tried it on; ſhe defired me then to be as quick as I could, becauſe it was ſupper-time.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you go away as ſoon as you had done?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: Yes; and came again the next day, and brought it home: I ſaw her then.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had you any converſation with her then?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: No; none.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you bring the ſtomacher?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: I aſked her to excuſe me till Monday; ſhe ſaid by all means, only let me have the gown by dreſſingtime to-morrow. And being in ſo great a hurry, going to ſupper, ſhe did not let me take the pins out; I told her I hoped ſhe would excuſe any little flaw that might happen. She ſaid ſhe would, by all means.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſee her on Sunday.

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: • did. There was Mrs. Dunning, the two ladies, Doctor Griffinburg, and another lady there. She appeared very briſk and merry; ſhe was coming to the fire to Dr. Griffinburg, and there ſtood talking.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had ſhe an opportunity to get out if ſhe would?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe had; ſhe was under no reſtraint, and was alone on the top of the ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did her eyes appear ſwelled with crying?

sp.speaker: Okeley.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt.

div.p: I am a milliner, and live in Holborn; I was ſent for to Lord Baltimore's; I ſaw a young lady; I did not know who ſhe was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What did ſhe beſpeak?

sp.speaker: Hadley.
sp.p: She choſe a cap and a cloak, and ſome petticoats, and ordered ſome muſlin to be brought.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe ſhew any attention to the faſhion and make of the goods?

sp.speaker: Hadley.
sp.p: I ſhewed her ſome; ſhe did not chuſe them. She did not ſay any thing particular, only objected to a cloak that it was too dear.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: The queſtion is, Did ſhe want them ſaſhionable?—There were under petticoats?

sp.speaker: Hadley.
sp.p: Yes; ſlannel petticoats.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe give any directions how theſe were to be made?

sp.speaker: Hadley.
sp.p: She deſired theſe might be made to tye before, and they muſt be brought home by two o'clock. I never had ſuch an order before.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did this young woman appear eaſy and chearful?

sp.speaker: Hadley.
sp.p: She did not ſeem diſtreſſed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cox.
sp.p: You never ſaw any tears, or any thing of that ſort?

sp.speaker: Hadley.
sp.p: No; none at all.

div.p: I am a muſician.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you teach any body muſic at my houſe?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: I taught Lord Baltimore's two daughters every day.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p:
Do you remember going to my houſe
in December? You know the time I refer to; you came to ſee ſome company in the parlour.

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: No; they were up ſtairs: it was the 28th of December.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What time of the day?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: Between eleven and twelve.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When you came there, where was I?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: I did not ſee Lord Baltimore at firſt when I came in; firſt I met Mrs. Saunier and a ſtrange woman I did not know.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who did ſhe turn out to be afterwards?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: After that I went to the room to my ſcholars, and there was the eldeſt daughter and my Lord; they deſired me to go and fetch a muſic-book from below; when I came up ſtairs into the room, I found his Lordſhip and the young woman, Miſs Woodcock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Have you ſeen her ſince?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: That was the only time I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When you came back again, you ſaw ſomebody in the parlour; did you not?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: I ſaw his Lordſhip and Miſs Woodcock playing together. She had her back to the fire ſide, and ſhe was handling her work. My Lord took her work from her, and pulled it from her; and ſhe pulled it from him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What was the work?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: A handkerchief, or ſome ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: She was not crying, or weeping then?

sp.speaker: Humell.
sp.p: No; ſhe was gay and free.

div.p: I am butler to my Lord at his houſe in Southamptonrow. I remember Miſs Woodcock's going out, on Monday the 28th of December, with Mrs. Griffinburg and Miſs Fanny. She is eight years old. They went in a hackney-coach. I handed them all in.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe go there freely?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Under no conſtraint?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: no; not in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did you ſee them all go freely into the coach? They were to drive to Queen-ſtreet, Soho?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: You being the butler, very frequently attend the hall, and go to the door, do you not?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Is the door ever locked in the day time?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Are you pretty much in the hall?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was any order given to ſtop her if ſhe ſhould want to go out?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Should you have ſtopped her, if ſhe had offered to go out?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Baker.
sp.p: The time you ſpeak of was Monday the 28th; when did you firſt ſee Miſs Woodcock?

sp.speaker: Burn.
sp.p: I believe the day they went down to Woodcote: that was the firſt time I had ever ſeen her.

div.p: I am ſervant to Dr. Griffinburg.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember any body coming in a coach to Dr. Griffinburg's on the 28th December?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p: Yes; Mrs. Griffinburg, Miſs Fanny, and Miſs Woodcock. When they came, I opened the door.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who came out firſt?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p: Mrs. Griffinburg.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where did the coach ſtop?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p: About five or ſix doors off. Mrs. Griffinburg took Miſs Fanny out, and brought her into the paſſage, and Miſs Woodcock followed.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where did they go?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p: Into the parlour. Mrs. Griffinburg came down twice or three times into the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How long was ſhe out of the parlour at a time?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p: About eight or ten minutes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then nobody was left with Miſs Woodcock but Miſs Fanny. Was the ſtreet door ſo faſtened that ſhe could not open it?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p: No? it was not faſtened at all: ſhe could have gone to the door in a minute.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember the parlour fire being out?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p:
I made it up. Miſs Woodcock ſaid ſhe was cold. Mrs. Griffinburg took her cloak, and put it on
her. She ſaid, Madam, you'll ſpoil me. She ſeemed merry.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Not at all dejected?

sp.speaker: Jacobs.
sp.p: No.

div.p: I am fourteen years old.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When was you fourteen?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: A quarter of a year ago.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Don't you live with Dr. Griffinburg?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember any thing of any company coming to your maſter's houſe in December?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Who were they?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Miſs Woodcock, Mrs. Griffinburgh, and Miſs Fanny.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How did they come?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: They came in a coach.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you know where they ſtopt?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: They ſtopt at a milk-cellar.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How far is that from your ſtreet-door?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: About five yards.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Then they were obliged to walk five yards to your door. Could the coach have come nearer up to the door?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What room did they go into?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: The back parlour.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Is that on the ground floor?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How far is it from the door of that parlour to your ſtreet door?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: About three yards.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When Mrs. Griffinburg was come home, there was ſome dinner preparing, was there not?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: There was.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did ſhe ſtay in the room all the time?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No; ſhe went down ſtairs: the firſt time, ſhe ſtaid a quarter of an hour, I believe, and went again after that.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Could ſhe have gone to the door, and let herſelf out, if ſhe pleaſed?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes, ſhe could.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was nobody with her beſides the little girl?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No; there was not.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When did they come?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: At four o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: That was day-light, was it not?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Yes.

div.p: I am a ſervant of Lord Baltimore's. I went to Dr. Griffinburg.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did not you go from thence to Whitechapel?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: Yes; I went with Lord Baltimore, Dr. Griffinburg, Sarah Woodcock, Miſs Fanny, and Mr. Morris.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray what time did you get to the tavern?

sp.speaker: Vanburgh.
sp.p: It might be between eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: How long might you ſtay there?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: It might be two hours. Miſs Woodcock, Miſs Fanny, and I, were left by ourſelves in that tavern in Whitechapel.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where were the others gone to?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: I don't know; they went out of the room.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had Miſs Woodcock any opportunity to get out of that room, if ſhe pleaſed? If ſhe had offered to go out of the room, ſhould you have ſtopped her?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: No; I had no ſuch orders; and if I had, I ſhould not have pretended to have ſtopped her.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where did Miſs Woodcock lie that night?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: I ſaw her in my Lord's bed.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Pray how did ſhe go to bed?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: She went up ſtairs; ſhe ſat ſome time in the room before ſhe went to bed; ſhe was as chearful as any perſon could be, and was very merry.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was the under any reſtraint?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: No; ſhe was under no reſtraint whatever.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Had ſhe her liberty?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: She had her full liberty.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Do you remember her going to my Lord Mansfield's? Do you know what became of the key of the door where ſhe lodged?

sp.speaker: Vanburg.
sp.p: She put it in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: I am a linen-draper.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Have you any connection with theſe people? How came you one of the party at the Crown and Magpye?

sp.speaker: Morris,
sp.p: Dr. Griffinburg had paid me ſome money that day, and he deſired me to carry a letter.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: For what reaſon?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: Becauſe he could not ſpeak Engliſh very well.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Did he direct you where to go?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: No; he went with me in the coach. We went to the Crown and Magpye, Whitechapal. I aſked Dr. Griffinburg what was the matter? He ſaid nothing at all. I followed him into the room.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Where was the room?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: On the ground floor. I paſſed by the bar; there was a woman ſelling of oyſters on one hand, and two or three people in the bar, and ſeveral in the kitchen, all of which we paſſed; and I ſaw in one room a dozen people.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What paſſed when you got into the room?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: Miſs Woodcock aſked who had got the letter? I ſaid, I have. She took the letter out of my pocket, and ſaid, this is my own hand writing; go and tell my father or ſiſter to come here directly. I went. Mrs. Berry ſaid, they were not at home, and could not tell when they would come home. I went back to my Lord again. He was for ſending me to Juſtice Fielding to enquire for Mr. Woodcock. Miſs Woodcock thought Juſtice Fielding would do no buſineſs at that time of night, and her father would probably be at home ſoon. We ſtaid about half an hour. She propoſed ſending the letter, and leaving it there. My Lord aſked her if ſhe thought Mrs. Berry would deliver the letter? She ſaid ſhe would. She propoſed writing a ſew more lines. She opened the letter, and wrote. My Lord deſired to ſee what ſhe wrote. She read it to him. There were about five or ſix lines. I went and gave the letter to Mrs. Berry. Mr. Woodcock was not yet come home.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: If this young woman had wanted to have gone herſelf to her father could any body have hindered her?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p:
She ſtood between me and the door. There was nothing could hinder her from going out, if ſhe
choſe to lift up the latch of the door. We went back, and I was ſet down at Bridges-ſtreet to go to Sir John Fielding's. My Lord deſired me to aſk for Miſs Woodcock's father and ſiſter, and deſire them to come to her at Dr. Griffinburg's houſe. When I went there, I could not find her father. I was carried directly to Sir John. He aſked me, how I came to go with them? I told him Dr. Griffinburg aſked me to go with a letter. He called one of his clerks to write a card to Miſs Woodcock, to deſire her to come to him to meet her father and friends there. I went with Mr. Lee, one of Sir John Fielding's clerks, to Dr. Griffinburg's. He delivered the card to Miſs Woodcock. I was rather frightned by Sir John. He told me it was a dangerous affair, and adviſed me to have nothing more to do with it. I ſaid I would not.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Was the card deſiring her to come that night, or ſome other time, to meet her father?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: That night.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Was not her father then at Sir John's that night?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: Was not you ſent to enquire whether the father was not at Sir John Fielding's?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: They never ſatisfied me?

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: What was the anſwer ſhe made on delivering the card? What did ſhe ſay with regard to Sir John?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: The laſt words ſhe ſaid was, But deſire them to come to Dr. Griffinburg's.

sp.speaker: Lord Baltimore.
sp.p: When ſhe was at the tavern writing that letter, did I give any direction to her?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: I did not hear my Lord ſay a ſingle word. It was all wrote by her own hand, and of her own dictating.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serj. Leigh.
sp.p: Was my Lord Baltimore in the room?

sp.speaker: Morris.
sp.p: Yes.

THE priſoner at the bar, Lord Baltimore, ſtands indicted for feloniouſly raviſhing and carnally knowing Sarah Woodcock, ſpinſter, againſt her will, on the 22d of December laſt at Epſom; againſt the ſtatute which makes this offence felony: and the other two priſoners are indicted as acceſſaries before the fact, by feloniouſly and maliciouſly procuring, aiding and abetting Lord Baltimore, to commit the ſaid rape, at the ſaid time and place. To this they have pleaded Not Guilty; and you are to try if they are guilty. Before I ſtate to you the evidence, I will mention to you two or three things: In the firſt place, my Lord complains of libels, and printed accounts of this tranſaction, which have been circulated. It is a moſt unjuſtifiable practice, and tends to the perverſion of public juſtice; and therefore if you have ſeen any thing printed on the ſide of the proſecut • ix or the priſoners, I muſt deſire you to diveſt yourſelves of any prejudice that ſuch publications may have occaſioned, and give your verdict only on the evidence now laid before you. Another thing I deſire, is, that whichever way the verdict is given, none of the friends of any of the parties will make uſe of any expreſſion of approbation o • applauſe, which are extremely improper and indecent in a court of juſtice, and I ſhall certainly commit any perſon whom I ſhall know to be guilty of it. The laſt thing I ſhall mention to you, is, to deſire that no reſentment you may feel at the manner in which ſhe was carried to Lord Baltimore's houſe, may have any influence on your verdict; for however unwarrantable the manner was, in which ſhe came into his power, if at the time he lay with her it was by her conſent, he is not guilty of the offence of which he is indicted; though it was proper to be given in evidence in this trial, to account for her being with him, and his having an opportunity of committing the crime; and to ſhew, from the indirect manner of getting her to his houſe, the greater probability that her account is true. Having ſaid this, I will now ſtate to you the whole evidence as particularly as I can.

p.hi: Mr. Baron Smythe then ſtated the whole of the evidence to the jury, as before given, which took up three hours, and on account of the length of it is not repeated here; and then concluded,

sp.p:
In point of law, the fact is fully proved on my Lord and the other two priſoners, if you believe the evidence of Sarah Woodcock. It is a crime which in its nature can only be proved by the woman on whom it is committed; for ſhe only can tell whether ſhe conſented or no; it is, as my Lord obſerves, very eaſy to be made, and hard to be diſproved; and the deſence can only be collected from circumſtances; from theſe you muſt judge whether her evidence is or is not to be believed. Lord Hale, in his hiſtory of the pleas of the crown Vol. I. p. 632, •
, lays down two rules: I. If complaint is not made ſoon after the injury is ſuppoſed to be received; 2. If it is not followed by a recent proſecution; a ſtrong preſumption ariſes that the complaint is malicious. She has owned the injury was received December 21ſt, and the complaint was not made till December 29th; but ſhe has accounted for it in the manner you have heard. The ſtrong part of the caſe, on behalf of the priſoners, is, her not complaining when ſhe was at Lord Mansfield's, the ſupreme magiſtrate in the kingdom in criminal matters: you have heard how ſhe has explained and accounted for her conduct in that particular, which you will judge of. Upon the whole, if you believe that ſhe made the diſcovery as ſoon as ſhe knew ſhe had an opportunity of doing it, and that her account is true, you will find all the priſoners guilty; if you believe that the did not make the diſcovery as ſoon as ſhe had an opportunity, and from thence, or other circumſtances, are not ſatisfied her account is true, you will find them all not guilty; for if he is not guilty, they cannot be ſo; for they cannot be acceſſary to a crime which was never committed.

p.hi: After Baron Smythe's ſumming up of the evidence, the jury went out for about an hour and twenty minutes, and then returned to the court.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, are you all agreed on your verdict?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arr.
sp.p: Who ſhall ſay for you?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Our Foreman.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arr.
sp.p: Frederick Calvert, Eſq Baron of Baltimore, hold up your hand. (which he did) Gentlemen of the Jury, look upon the priſoners: How ſay you, is Frederick Calvert, Eſq Baron of Baltimore, guilty of this felony and rape whereof he ſtands indicted, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Not guilty.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arr.
sp.p: How ſay you, Gentlemen, is Elizabeth Griffinburgh guilty of this felony and rape whereof ſhe ſtands indicted, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Not guilty.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arr.
sp.p: How ſay you, Gentlemen, is Ann Harvey, otherwiſe Darby, guilty of this felony and rape whereof ſhe ſtands indicted, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Jury.
sp.p: Not guilty.

sp.speaker: Clerk of Arr.
sp.p: Harken to your verdict, as the court hath recorded it. You ſay that Frederick Calvert, Eſq Baron of Baltimore, in the kingdom of Ireland, is not guilty, and ſo you ſay all.
And you ſay that Elizabeth Griffinburg and Ann Harvey are not guilty, and ſo you ſay all.
